{{Infobox noble|type | name = Himiltrude | title = | image = | caption = | alt = | CoA = | more = no | succession = | reign = | reign-type = | predecessor = | successor = | spouse = [[Charlemagne]] | spouse-type = Concubine or Wife of | issue = {{startplainlist}} [[Pepin the Hunchback]] | issue-link = | issue-pipe = | full name = | styles = | titles = | noble family = | house-type = | father = | mother = | birth_date = 742? | birth_place = | christening_date = | christening_place = | death_date = 780? | death_place = | burial_date = | burial_place = | religion = | occupation = | memorials = | url = <!-- {{{URL|example.com}} --> | module = }}
'''Himiltrude''' (c. 742-c.780?) was the mother of [[Charlemagne]]'s first-born son [[Pippin the Hunchback]].
==Life==
Little is known about Himiltrude's origins. [[Paulus Diaconus]] calls her a "noble girl".<ref name="Konecny">Silvia Konecny, ''Die Frauen des karolingischen Königshauses. Die politische Bedeutung der Ehe und die Stellung der Frau in der fränkischen Herrscherfamilie vom 7. bis zum 10. Jahrhundert.'', [http://www.mittelalter-genealogie.de/karolinger_familie_karls/himiltrud_frankenkoenigin_769.html p. 65] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081207182933/http://www.mittelalter-genealogie.de/karolinger_familie_karls/himiltrud_frankenkoenigin_769.html |date=2008-12-07 }}.</ref> The appearance of her name in the fraternity books of [[Alemannia]]n monasteries may suggest an affiliation with the [[Germanic peoples|Germanic]] Alemannian or Alsatian nobility,<ref name="Hägermann">Dieter Hägermann, ''Karl der Große. Herrscher des Abendlands'', Ullstein 2003, p. 82f.</ref> while other sources make her the daughter of a Burgundian count and a granddaughter of Grimbert I, Count of Paris. It is not possible, however, to extrapolate any political ramifications from Charlemagne's relationship with Himiltrude.<ref name="Konecny"/>
Himiltrude probably entered into a relationship with Charlemagne during the lifetime of his father, [[Pepin the Younger]].<ref name="Konecny"/> When Charlemagne acceded to the throne in 768, Himiltrude remained unnamed in official sources – contrary to the example set by Charlemagne's mother, [[Bertrada of Laon]].<ref name="Konecny"/> Himiltrude bore Charles a son called [[Pepin the Hunchback|Pépin]]. Shortly after Pepin's birth, an alliance was formulated between Charlemagne and the King of the Lombards, [[Desiderius]]. To seal the alliance, it was agreed that Charlemagne should marry Desiderius' daughter (called [[Desiderata of the Lombards|Desiderata]] by modern scholars).
Himiltrude was dismissed at that time and disappears from historical records. A grave excavated in the monastery of [[Nivelles]] was found to contain the corpse of a forty-year-old woman, possibly identifiable with Himiltrude. If so, Himiltrude would appear to have died long after 770, although if and when she retired to Nivelles cannot be deduced.<ref name="Konecny"/>
Her son Pépin, who suffered from a spinal deformity and was called "the Hunchback", was eclipsed by Charlemagne's sons from his later marriage to [[Hildegard of Vinzgouw|Hildegard]]. Following an attempted rebellion against his father, Pepin was confined to a monastery.<ref name="Konecny"/>
==Marital status== The nature of Himiltrude's relationship to Charlemagne is a matter of dispute. Charlemagne's biographer [[Einhard]] calls her a "concubine"<ref>Einhard, ''[[Vita Karoli Magni]]'', ch. 20</ref> and [[Paulus Diaconus]] speaks of Pippin's birth "before legal marriage",<ref name="Konecny"/> whereas a letter by [[Pope Stephen III]] refers to Charlemagne and his brother Carloman as being already married (to Himiltrude and [[Gerberga, wife of Carloman I|Gerberga]]), and advises them not to dismiss their wives.<ref name="Konecny"/>
Historians have interpreted the information in different ways. Some, such as [[Pierre Riché]], follow Einhard in describing Himiltrude as a concubine.<ref>Pierre Riché, ''The Carolingians'', p.86.</ref> Others, Dieter Hägemann for example, consider Himiltrude a wife in the full sense.<ref name="Hägermann"/> Still others subscribe to the idea that the relationship between the two was "something more than concubinage, less than marriage" and describe it as a [[Friedelehe]], a supposed form of marriage unrecognized by the Church and easily dissolvable. This form of relationship is often seen in a conflict between Christian marriage and more flexible Germanic concepts.<ref name="Konecny"/>

{{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Musicians --> | name = Ignacio Corsini | image = Ignacio Corsini.jpg | alt = | caption = Ignacio Corsini | image_size = 240px | background = solo_singer | birth_name = | alias = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1891|02|13}} | death_date = {{Death date and age|1967|07|26|1891|02|13}} | origin = [[Troina]], [[Italy]] | instrument = | genre = [[Argentine music#Folk music|Folklore]], [[Argentine Tango|tango]] | occupation = | years_active = | label = | associated_acts = | website = | current_members = | past_members = }} '''Ignacio Corsini''' (February 13, 1891 – July 26, 1967) was an [[Italian people|Italian]]-born [[Argentine]] [[Argentine music#Folk music|folklore]] and [[Argentine Tango|tango]] musician.
==Life and work== Andrés Ignacio Corsini was born in [[Troina]], a village in the [[Enna]] Province of [[Sicily]], in 1891. He was the illegitimate son of Socorro Salomone and a local man whose identity was never revealed publicly—save for his being a Corsini (hence the child's last name). Ms. Salomone left [[Italy]] for [[Buenos Aires]], [[Argentina]] in 1896, and settled in the middle-class [[Almagro, Buenos Aires|Almagro]] section of the city. They settled in [[Carlos Tejedor, Buenos Aires|Carlos Tejedor]], then a small [[pampas]] town where Corsini would spend the remainder of his childhood, finding work as an [[bullock cart|ox cart]] driver and [[herder|herdsman]].<ref name=tango>[http://www.todotango.com/english/creadores/icorsini.asp Todo Tango: Ignacio Corsini]</ref>
Corsini returned in 1907 to the Almagro section of Buenos Aires, where he was influenced by folk singer [[José Betinotti]] and a [[circus]] performer, José Pacheco. Pacheco introduced him to the [[Argentine culture#Cinema and theatre|theatre]] and to his own daughter, Victoria Pacheco, whom Corsini would marry in 1911. He went on to perform in numerous theatre companies and circuses, and in 1912, he was awarded a recording contract by [[RCA Victor]]. His interpretation of traditional folklore standards earned him singing roles in numerous [[Argentine cinema|Argentine films]] in subsequent years, mostly in [[period piece]]s set during Argentina's pastoral 19th century. These included: ''Santos Vega'' (1916), ''¡Federación o muerte!'' (1917) and ''Milonguita'' (1922).<ref name=tango/>
Having never attended a [[music conservatory]], Corsini once attributed his unmistakable [[falsetto]] to his bucolic pampas upbringing, recalling that ''"birds taught me the spontaneity of their singing, without witnesses and in the great scenery of nature."'' <ref name=tango/>
Corsini also earned renown as a [[Argentine tango|tango]] vocalist, however. Initially avoiding the genre, he included one tango piece, "Un lamento," in a 1920 album. Well received, this recording would remain his sole foray into tango until, in 1922, he was persuaded to premiere "Patotero sentimental" in a [[sainete]] (stage comedy), "El bailarín del cabaret." Corsini secured his standing in the world of tango by popularizing [[Juan de Dios Filiberto]]'s soulful [[Milonga (music)|milonga]], "[[Caminito]]," in 1927. Written as an ode to what was then an oft-used shortcut in the blue-collar [[La Boca]] section of Buenos Aires, "Caminito" remains one of the most recognizable Argentine songs of any genre.<ref name=tango/>
"El Caballero Cantor"—the "gentleman singer," as he was known by then—Corsini was also a composer and lyricist of numerous tangos, such as, among others, "Flor marchita," and "Aquel cantor de mi pueblo" (music by [[guitar]]ist [[Enrique Maciel]]). The latter was immortalized by Corsini's one-time film co-star, [[Edmundo Rivero]]. He also composed in other genres, writing folklore pieces (such as "Tradición gaucha" and "A mi palomita"), and a [[waltz]]: "Tristeza criolla," based on a poem by [[Julián de Charras]].
A 1929 songbook written as an ode to the era of 19th century strongman [[Juan Manuel de Rosas]] by poet [[Héctor Blomberg]] and guitarist [[Enrique Maciel]] featured Corsini as the lead vocalist, a performance considered by critics to have been th highlight of the album.<ref>[http://www.todotango.com/english/biblioteca/cronicas/la_pulpera.asp Todo Tango: Ignacio Corsini, the one who saved ''La Pulpera''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090815092159/http://www.todotango.com/english/biblioteca/cronicas/la_pulpera.asp |date=2009-08-15 }}</ref> His performance of the album's title track, "La pulpera de Santa Lucía," was critical to its being aired on the [[Communications of Argentina#Radio|radio]]. This return to folklore was followed by similar performances on film, including ''Rapsodia gaucha'' (1932), ''Ídolos de la radio'' (1934, memorable also for a duet between two standards of tango, [[Ada Falcón]] and [[Carlos Gardel]]), and the [[western movie]]-styled ''Fortín alto'' (1941), where he was featured with [[Agustín Irusta]] and a then-unknown [[Edmundo Rivero]].<ref name=tango/>
These successes were dealt a bitter turn by the death of his wife Victoria, on May 28, 1949, following which he retired as a performer. Corsini penned his memoirs the following year, in which he wrote that ''"in her I found the great partner of all my life, who encouraged me in my uncertain hours and to whom I owe a great part of my success"'' (the autobiography was never published).<ref name=tango/>
Corsini reappeared in 1961 for a Channel 7 special, "Volver a vivir" ("To Live Again"). This would be his last public performance, however, and on July 26, 1967, the 'gentleman singer' died at age 76.

{{Infobox person | name = Irene Dölling | image = | caption = | image_size = | other_names = Irene Mayer-Dölling | birth_date = 23 December 1942 | birth_place = [[Leicester]], [[England]] | death_date = | death_place = | party = | occupation = [[Sociology|Sociologist]] ([[Women's studies]]) | parents = | spouse = | children = }}
'''Irene Dölling''' (also known as '''Irene Mayer-Dölling''') (born 23 December 1942) is a [[Germany|German]] [[Sociology|sociologist]].<ref name=EUComID>{{cite web |url=http://ec.europa.eu/research/science-society/women/enwise/pdf/dolling.pdf|title=Professor Irene Dölling|publisher=The European Commission (Research and Innovation) |accessdate=12 March 2015}}</ref> She is now an [[Emeritus]] [[Professor]] in [[Women's studies]], having retired from her full-time role at [[University of Potsdam|Potsdam University]] early in 2008.<ref name=BiographischeDatenbankenID>{{cite web|url=http://bundesstiftung-aufarbeitung.de/wer-war-wer-in-der-ddr-%2363%3B-1424.html?ID=601|author1= Jan Wielgohs |author2= |title=Dölling, Irene *23.12.1942 Kulturwissenschaftlerin |publisher= Bundesstiftung zur Aufarbeitung der SED-Diktatur: Biographische Datenbanken |language= German| accessdate= 12 March 2015}}</ref> She serves on the advisory board of the feminist academic journal ''[[Signs (journal)|Signs]]''.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://signsjournal.org/about-signs/masthead/|title=Masthead|date=2012-08-22|work=Signs: Journal of Women in Culture and Society|access-date=2017-08-31|language=en-US}}</ref>
At the time of her retirement her colleague [[Regina Becker-Schmidt]] commended Dölling for qualities that included her "creative obstinacy" ''{{lang|de|("kreative Eigensinn")}}''.<ref name=UniPotID>{{cite web |url=http://www.pnn.de/campus/9158/|title=Nicht mit allen Winden segeln: Verabschiedung der Professorin für Frauenforschung Irene Dölling von der Uni Potsdam|author=Marie Preißler|publisher=Potsdamer Zeitungsverlagsgesellschaft mbH & Co. KG: (Potsdamer Neueste Nachrichten)|date=15 February 2008|accessdate=12 March 2015}}</ref>
==Life==
===Early years=== Dölling was born during the [[Second World War]] in [[Leicester]] in [[England]]<ref name=BiographischeDatenbankenID/> with political refugees as parents.<ref name=WegeindieSozID>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=9_KHUfEjd7QC&pg=PA116&lpg=PA116&dq=%22Irene+D%C3%B6lling%22+Leicester&source=bl&ots=jQvGfvBmAI&sig=AUs9PzhAH56uPGGe5l1M4KXAsCo&hl=en&sa=X&ei=980BVafnKabD7gaXkYHoCA&ved=0CDkQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=%22Irene%20D%C3%B6lling%22%20Leicester&f=false| title=Arbeiten zwischen den Diziplinen| author1=Irene Dölling| work=Wege in die Soziologie und die Frauen- und Geschlechterforschung: Autobiographische Notizen der ersten Generation von Professorinnen an der Universität|author2= Ulrike Vogel (editor)|date= 2006|accessdate=12 March 2015|publisher=Springer-Verlag GmbH, Heidelberg,Zweigniederlassung der Springer-Verlag GmbH, Berlin (also seems to be accessible online using Google books at present - March 2015)}}</ref> The family were ethnic Germans as well as members of the [[Communist Party of Czechoslovakia|Communist Party]].<ref name=WegeindieSozID/> They had campaigned actively against [[Nazism]] during the 1930s, and had been living in what was at the time [[Czechoslovakia]] with Czechoslovak passports. However, in 1938 [[Nazi Germany]] started a project through the use of military force to incorporate Czechoslovakia into an enlarged German state.<ref name=WegeindieSozID/> The Döllings fled to Britain in 1939.<ref name=WegeindieSozID/>
Her father had worked in the textiles industry before the war (and would return to the trade when he was able to return to the European mainland).<ref name=WegeindieSozID/> Her mother's work lied in the garment industry.<ref name=BiographischeDatenbankenID/> Irene Dölling would later recall that her mother, as the eldest of six children, had been forced to cut her schooling short when her mother (Irene's grandmother) fell ill, and the eldest daughter was called upon to look after the family.<ref name=WegeindieSozID/>
===Soviet occupation zone/German Democratic Republic=== Dölling was not yet 3 when the war ended in May 1945. During a period of [[Expulsion of Germans from Czechoslovakia|wholesale ethnic cleansing]] there was no longer any question of the German speaking Dölling family returning to Czechoslovakia, where they had lived until 1939. Instead, they established themselves in the [[Soviet occupation zone]] of what remained of Germany.<ref name=WegeindieSozID/> By 1946 her father had returned to work in the textiles industry, and Irene Dölling grew up as one of two children in a family home that she later remembers as "bookish and intellectually stimulating."<ref name=WegeindieSozID/> Meanwhile, the Soviet occupation zone formally became the [[German Democratic Republic]] in October 1949. A stand-alone East German state [[Group of Soviet Forces in Germany|sponsored]] by the [[Soviet Union]] on which its [[One-party state|one-]] [[Socialist Unity Party of Germany|party]] [[Constitution of East Germany|constitutional]] arrangements were modelled. It was here that Dölling made her life until the separate East German [[Die Wende|state dissolved]] in [[German reunification|1989/90]]. In 1961 Dölling passed her school [[Abitur]] final exams in [[Berlin]].<ref name=BiographischeDatenbankenID/>
Between 1961 and 1966 she studied [[Library science]] and [[Philosophy]] at Berlin's [[Humboldt University of Berlin|Humboldt University]].<ref name=BiographischeDatenbankenID/> The library science represented a job ticket, but the philosophy became a lasting interest. Philosophy at this time was taught within the framework of [[Marxism]] as officially defined.<ref name=WegeindieSozID/> After obtaining her degree she remained at the Humboldt as a research assistant and working for her doctorate which she received in 1970.<ref name=BiographischeDatenbankenID/> Her dissertation was entitled "On Marxist theories of the driving forces of the practical behaviours of individuals: some preconditions of socialist cultural theory and society".<ref>''"Zur marxistischen Theorie der Triebkräfte praktischgeistigen Verhaltens der Individuen : Zu einigen Voraussetzgn d. Kulturtheorie d. sozialist. Gesellschaft "''</ref><ref name=DNBIDProm>{{cite web |url=https://portal.dnb.de/opac.htm?method=showFullRecord&currentResultId=%22106719939%22%26any&currentPosition=15 |title=Katalog der Deutschen Nationalbibliothek |publisher=Deutsche Nationalbibliothek, Frankfurt am Main|date=1970|accessdate=13 March 2015}}</ref> Her [[Habilitation]] followed in 1976.<ref name=BiographischeDatenbankenID/><ref>''"Die kulturtheoretische Konzeption der Persönlichkeit : zur Rolle der biologischen Konstitution im Prozess der Persönlichkeitsentwicklung; weltanschauliche und methodologische Aspekte"''</ref><ref name=DNBIDHab>{{cite web |url=https://portal.dnb.de/opac.htm?method=showFullRecord&currentResultId=%22106719939%22%26any&currentPosition=14 |title=Katalog der Deutschen Nationalbibliothek |publisher=Deutsche Nationalbibliothek, Frankfurt am Main|date=1975|accessdate=13 March 2015}}</ref>
Irene Dölling stayed at the Humboldt, subject to a couple of brief breaks, right up till 1994. In 1985 she was appointed Professor for [[Culture theory]] in the university's [[Cultural studies]] and [[Aesthetics]] Department.<ref name=BiographischeDatenbankenID/> By this time she had already started to focus on gender relations and the position of women in East German society.<ref name=EUComID/> The slaughter of the [[Second World War|war]] had left Germany with a shortage of working age citizens which in the case of [[East Germany]] was exacerbated during the 1940/50s by the emigration of several million working-age East Germans to [[West Germany|the west]].<ref>"In the period between the Second World War and 1961, a total of 3.8 million people emigrated from East to West Germany." Laar, M. (2009). "The Power of Freedom. Central and Eastern Europe after 1945." Centre for European Studies, p. 58. {{cite web|url=http://www.poweroffreedombook.com/preview_PoF.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-04-05 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131111025246/http://www.poweroffreedombook.com/preview_PoF.pdf |archivedate=2013-11-11 |df= }}</ref> Partly as a result of this, female participation in the work force was relatively high in the [[German Democratic Republic]], which correlated with a commensurate increased level of economic (though not, at least at higher levels, political) status and empowerment for women. By the time Dölling's research interests came to focus on gender issues, roughly 90% of women of working age, supported by state organised child care provision, were in full-time employment.<ref name=UniPotID/> [[German reunification]], formally enacted in 1990, threw into sharp focus a contrast with he situation in (what had till then been) [[West Germany]] where a far higher proportion of women of working age stayed at home looking after families; and if they were in paid employment, often working only part-time. Many feminist academics expressed a preference for the work/life balance on offer to women in pre-1990 East Germany, but in any case, as equalisation between the two halves of the country came about during the 1990s, there was no shortage of research topics for the academic staff and students in the [[Women's studies]] departments.<ref name=UniPotID/>
===German Federal Republic=== Irene Dölling co-founded, with {{Interlanguage link multi|Hildegard Maria Nickel|de}}, the [[:de:Zentrum für transdisziplinäre Geschlechterstudien|Centre for cross-disciplinary gender studies (ZtG / ''Zentrum für transdisziplinäre Geschlechterstudien'')]]<ref name=wasbedeutetZtG>{{cite web | url=http://www.gender.hu-berlin.de/zentrum|title=Das Zentrum für transdisziplinäre Geschlechterstudien |publisher=ZtG, Berlin|date=30 May 2013|accessdate=13 March 2015}}</ref> at the [[Humboldt University of Berlin|Humboldt University]] in on 8 December 1989. In 1990 she became the Centre's first Research Director.<ref name=BiographischeDatenbankenID/>
In 1994 she finally moved, albeit not very far away, becoming Professor for [[Women's studies]] at the Economic and Social Sciences faculty at the [[University of Potsdam]].<ref name=BiographischeDatenbankenID/> She remained here till her retirement in 2008.<ref name=UniPotID/> In addition to her teaching, she continued to publish her own work<ref name=DNBIDGes>{{cite web |url=https://portal.dnb.de/opac.htm?method=simpleSearch&query=106719939|title=Katalog der Deutschen Nationalbibliothek |publisher=Deutsche Nationalbibliothek, Frankfurt am Main|date=1970|accessdate=13 March 2015}}</ref> as well as serving on the scientific advisory boards of various academic journals in Germany<ref name=RosLuxID>{{cite web | url=http://www.rosalux.de/stiftung/gremien/wissenschaftlicher-beirat.html|title=Wissenschaftlicher Beirat|publisher=Rosa-Luxemburg-Stiftung: Gesellschaftsanalyse und politische Bildung e. V., Berlin|accessdate=13 March 2015}}</ref> and internationally.<ref name=SignsID>{{cite web |url=http://signsjournal.org/about-signs/masthead/ |title=Signs Masthead|publisher=Signs: Journal of Women in Culture and Society, Boston MA|date=2012|work=International Advisory Board|accessdate=13 March 2015 }}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|2}}

'''James Leander Cathcart''' (1 June 1767 – 6 October 1843) was a diplomat, [[Arab slave trade|slave]], and sailor. He is notable for his narrative as a slave in [[Algiers]] for eleven years.
==Revolutionary War == Cathcart was born in Mount Murragh, [[County Westmeath]], [[Ireland]] and emigrated to the North American colonies at eight years of age, under the care of a relative, Captain John Cathcart. He joined the [[American Revolution]] and at the age of twelve served on a [[privateer]]. Three years later, as a midshipman on ''The Confederacy'', he was captured by the British and imprisoned on the [[Prison ship|prisoner ships]], ''The Good Hope'' and {{HMS|Jersey|1736|2}} from which he escaped in 1782. He became fluent in Spanish and French, which he learned from fellow prisoners during his three-year internment.
== Slave in Algiers == In 1785 [[Barbary pirates]] captured the American merchant ship ''The Maria Boston'', on its way to Cadiz carrying furs, lumber, and dried codfish. They took Cathcart and twenty other sailors as [[Slavery|slaves]]. During the eleven years of his slavery in [[Algiers]] Cathcart managed by means of good fortune, cleverness, and bribery to improve his circumstances, eventually becoming chief clerk to the [[Dey]].<ref>Sears, Christine. [http://teachinghistory.org/best-practices/examples-of-historical-thinking/24298 The Barbary Pirates: Letter from Tripoli] [http://www.teachinghistory.org Teachinghistory.org]. Accessed 3 June 2011.</ref> In this position, he acted as a mediator between the [[Dey]] and Joseph Donaldson, Jr. agent for Colonel [[David Humphreys (soldier)|David Humphreys]], the U.S. Minister to Portugal, that resulted in [[The Treaty of Algiers of 1796]] and made possible his freedom.
Cathcart, for the first several years of his captivity, endured the same terrible living conditions as his fellow slaves. One of a few handpicked by the [[Dey]], Cathcart’s first duties were to work in the Dey’s palace garden caring for the lions, tigers, and antelopes. Although his assigned duties were relatively light, his masters provided scant food and administered several beatings, called [[bastinado]], where in one instance Cathcart lost several of his toenails.
As his fortunes and positions in [[Algiers]] improved, Cathcart acquired additional skills that he used later as a diplomat. He found opportunities to demonstrate his concern for his fellow prisoners. During his slavery he became conversant in Arabic and Turkish. When Cathcart became clerk of the prison, he was able to buy several taverns, a house with servants, and procure more food for his fellow crew members. After the Treaty of Algiers freed them, Cathcart had the means to purchase a ship, which he sailed to Philadelphia in 1796 with twelve surviving members of the original crew.
== Personal== On 5 June 1798 he married Philadelphia belle Jane Bancker Woodside, and they had twelve children. His daughter JB Newkirk put together Cathcart’s narrative and published it in 1899, 56 years after his death, under the title of ''The Captives, Eleven Years a Prisoner in Algiers''.
== Professional diplomatic career== He returned to the [[Barbary Coast]] in December 1798, as special agent to [[William Eaton (soldier)|William Eaton]]. In 1802, he was appointed [[Consul (representative)|US Consul]] to [[Tunis]] and [[Tripoli]]. He participated in the negotiation of additional treaties with [[Algiers]], Tunis, and Tripoli. He served as [[Consul (representative)|Consul-General]] for the United States in [[Cádiz]] from 1807–17, where he operated a merchant business with [[Richard Worsam Meade I|Richard Worsam Meade]].<ref>{{cite AV media|last=Atzbach|first=Nicole|date=2016|title=Portraits in Conversation: Francisco de Goya and Vicente López y Portaña|type=lecture|url=https://youtube.com/watch?v=EE0uT5tOAEU&t=40m16s|access-date=September 17, 2018|time=40m16s|publisher=[[Meadows Museum]]}}</ref> Cathcart served in the diplomatic corps for the United States during the administrations of [[John Adams]], [[Thomas Jefferson]], and [[James Madison]].

Rev Sir '''James Marchant''' [[FRSE]] FLS FRAS KBE LLD (1867-1956) was a British [[Eugenics|eugenicist]], social reformer and author. He was leader of the [[National Vigilance Association]], concerned with social morality, and also the Director of the [[National Council of Public Morals]]. He epitomises the view of the priggish Victorian attitude to sex and morality.<ref>Edwardian Turn of Mind, Samuel Hynes</ref>
==Life==
He was born in [[London]] on 18 December 1867.
In 1917 he was elected a Fellow of the [[Royal Society of Edinburgh]]. His proposers were Sir [[Thomas Clouston]], Sir [[Alexander Russell Simpson]], [[John Arthur Thomson]] and [[John William Ballantyne]]. He was created a Knight of the [[Order of the British Empire]] by King [[George V]] for his work on birth-rate and contraception in 1921, a rare accolade for a clergyman.<ref>{{cite book|title=Biographical Index of Former Fellows of the Royal Society of Edinburgh 1783–2002|date=July 2006|publisher=The Royal Society of Edinburgh|isbn=0 902 198 84 X|url=https://www.royalsoced.org.uk/cms/files/fellows/biographical_index/fells_indexp2.pdf}}</ref>
He died in [[Sherborne]] on 20 May 1956.
==Family==
In 1895 he married Eleanor Jane Gordon.
==Publications== *''Theories of the Resurrection of Christ'' (1896) *''Theories of the Person of Christ'' (1903) *''Social Hygienics: A New Crusade'' (1909) *''Aids to Purity'' (1909) *''A Plea for Regeneration'' (1912) *''The Cleansing of a City'' (1917) *''The Master Problem'' (1917) *''The Coming Renaissance'' (1923) *''British Preachers'' (1927) *''The Coming of Age of Christianity'' (1951) *''The Censorship of Low Orade Literature'' *''The Reunion of Christendom'' *''The Life of [[Alfred Russel Wallace]]''
==References== {{reflist}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2012}} {{Use British English|date=June 2012}} {{Infobox writer | name = Jancis Robinson | honorific_suffix = [[Order of the British Empire|OBE]], [[Order of Entrepreneurial Merit|ComMA]], [[Master of Wine|MW]] | image = JRkitchen-3 (1).JPG | imagesize = | caption = Robinson at home in 2010 | birth_name = Jancis Mary Robinson | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1950|4|22}} | birth_place = [[Cumbria]], [[England]] | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = Wine critic | nationality = British | subject = Wine | influences = | influenced = | awards = [[Order of the British Empire]] | website = {{URL|http://www.jancisrobinson.com/}} }}
'''Jancis Mary Robinson''' <small>[[Order of the British Empire|OBE]], [[Order of Entrepreneurial Merit|ComMA]], [[Master of Wine|MW]]</small> (born 22 April 1950) is a [[United Kingdom|British]] [[wine]] [[critic]], journalist and wine writer. She currently writes a weekly column for the ''[[Financial Times]]'', and writes for her website JancisRobinson.com, updated daily. She also provides advice for the wine cellar of [[Queen Elizabeth II]].<ref name="JR.com CV"/>
==Early life and education== Robinson was born in [[Cumbria]], studied [[mathematics]] and [[philosophy]] at [[St Anne's College, Oxford|St Anne's College]], [[University of Oxford]],<ref name=longbio>{{cite web|last=Robinson |first=Jancis |url=http://www.jancisrobinson.com/articles/a200808294.html |website=JancisRobinson.com |title=Jancis Robinson - the long version |accessdate=2014-06-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140703231955/http://www.jancisrobinson.com/articles/a200808294.html |archivedate= 3 July 2014 |df= }}</ref> and worked for a travel company after leaving university.{{citation needed|date=November 2012}}
==Career== Robinson started her [[wine writing]] career on 1 December 1975 when she became assistant editor for the trade magazine ''[[Wine & Spirit]]''.<ref name="JR.com CV">[http://www.jancisrobinson.com/articles/20070106_1 ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080214050732/http://www.jancisrobinson.com/articles/20070106_1 |date=14 February 2008 }}</ref> In 1984, she became the first person outside the wine trade to become a [[Master of Wine]]. From 1995 until she resigned in 2010 she served as [[British Airways]]' wine consultant, and supervised the BA [[Concorde]] cellar luxury selection.<ref name=wb>{{cite web| last= Hall |first= Lisa Shara, ''Wine Business Monthly'' |title= Wine Flies |date=3 March 2002|url=http://www.winebusiness.com/html/MonthlyArticle.cfm?dataId=15451 }}</ref>
As a wine writer, she has become one of the world's leading writers of educational and encyclopedic material on wine and was described by Decanter magazine as 'the most respected wine critic and journalist in the world'. ''[[The Oxford Companion to Wine]]'', edited by Robinson, is widely considered to be the most comprehensive wine encyclopedia in the world.<ref name=NYTeajr>{{cite news|last= Asimov |first= Eric, ''The New York Times'' |title=A Master of Wine Takes a Fresh Look |date=1 November 2006 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/11/01/dining/01janc.html?ei=5088&en=2b5ece1a3328ae09&ex=1320037200&partner=rssnyt&emc=rss&pagewanted=all }}</ref> The first edition was published in 1994, and took five years to write after she was signed on as editor in 1988.<ref>[http://gremolata.com/jancis.htm] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071026013648/http://gremolata.com/jancis.htm |date=26 October 2007 }}</ref> In addition, ''[[The World Atlas of Wine]]'' by [[Hugh Johnson (wine)|Hugh Johnson]] and Robinson is one of the world's leading wine atlases.<ref name=NYTeajr/>
In 1995, Jancis Robinson appeared in a 10-episode wine course on [[BBC 2]] television. This series was later reissued on [[DVD]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/Jancis-Robinsons-Complete-Collection-REGIONS/dp/B0052VXOG4 |title=Jancis Robinson's Wine Course ~ Complete Collection 2 Disc Set PAL ALL REGIONS: Amazon.co.uk: DVD & Blu-ray |publisher=Amazon.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2015-11-25}}</ref> A book titled ''Jancis Robinson's Wine Course'' was written to accompany the series and has gone through several editions. In 2015 she launched an online wine course, Mastering Wine - Shortcuts to Success, on www.udemy.com.<ref name="JR.com CV"/>
She has an honorary doctorate from the [[Open University]], and was made an [[Order of the British Empire|OBE]] in 2003, among numerous other awards for her writing. Her accolades include multiple [[Glenfiddich]] Awards and André Simon Memorial Awards, and a selection as the ''[[Decanter (magazine)|Decanter]]'' "1999 Woman of the Year". In 2016, she was made an Officier de l'Ordre du Mérite Agricole, was given the German VDP association's highest honour and won for fourth James Beard Award in the US.<ref name="JR.com CV"/>
Following a difference of opinion with [[Robert M. Parker, Jr.|Robert Parker]] over the 2003 vintage of [[Château Pavie]], the following media coverage frequently described a "war of words" between the two critics.<ref name=deca>{{cite web|last= Styles |first= Oliver, ''Decanter'' |title= Parker and Robinson in war of words |url= http://www.decanter.com/news/wine-news/488229/parker-and-robinson-in-war-of-words|publisher=Decanter.com |date= 14 April 2004 }}</ref><ref name=sf>{{cite news|last= Voss |first= Roger, ''San Francisco Chronicle'' |title= Robinson, Parker have a row over Bordeaux |url= http://www.sfgate.com/default/article/Robinson-Parker-have-a-row-over-Bordeaux-2755642.php |date= 27 May 2004 |work=The San Francisco Chronicle}}</ref> Less dramatic than the predominant press view, Robinson and Parker currently have a cordial relationship.<ref name=jr08>{{cite web|last= Robinson |first= Jancis |title=Parker and Robinson in clinch | url= http://www.jancisrobinson.com/articles/20080331|publisher=Jancisrobinson.com |date= 31 March 2008 }}</ref>
In 2012, Allen Lane (Penguin) in the UK and Ecco in the US published a 1,200-page book called ''Wine Grapes'' co-authored by Robinson with Julia Harding MW and Jose Vouillamoz which won every major wine book award. The book provides comprehensive details on 1,368 vine varieties and won six major wine book awards.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://winegrapes.org/ |title=The most complete guide to vine varieties and their wines ever |publisher=Wine Grapes |date=2014-06-20 |accessdate=2015-11-25}}</ref>
Robinson is married to the food writer [[Nick Lander]], author of ''The Art of the Restaurateur''; they have three children, Julia, William and Rose.<ref name="JR.com CV"/>
==Honours== *[[File:Order of the British Empire (Civil) Ribbon.png|80px]] Officer of the [[Order of the British Empire]], [[United Kingdom]] (2003) *[[File:Ordre du Merite agricole Officier 1999 ribbon.svg|80px]] Officer of the [[Order of Agricultural Merit]], [[France]] (2010) <ref>{{cite web|title=Jancis Robinson - the long version|url=https://www.jancisrobinson.com/jancis-robinson-the-long-version|website=Jancis Robinson|accessdate=31 July 2017}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|title=Jancis Robinson |url=http://www.chartwellspeakers.com/speaker/jancis-robinson/|website=Chartwell Speakers|accessdate=31 July 2017}}</ref> *[[File:POR Ordem do Merito Agricola Comendador BAR.svg|80px]] Commander of the [[Order of Entrepreneurial Merit]] (Category of Agricultural Merit), [[Portugal]] (2011)<ref>{{cite web|title=Cidadãos Nacionais Agraciados com Ordens Portuguesas|url=http://www.ordens.presidencia.pt/?idc=154|website=Página Oficial das Ordens Honoríficas Portuguesas|accessdate=31 July 2017}}</ref>
==Bibliography== *{{cite book| first = Jancis | last = Robinson | title = [[The 24-Hour Wine Expert]] | publisher = Penguin|year= 2016 | isbn = 978-0-141-98181-9}} *{{cite book| first = Jancis | last = Robinson |author2=Murphy, Linda | title = [[American Wine]] | publisher = University of California Press|year= 2013 | isbn = 978-1-84533-528-1 | id = {{ISBN|978-0-520-27321-4}}}} *{{cite book| first = Jancis | last = Robinson |author2=Harding, Julia |author3=Vouillamoz, José | title = [[Wine Grapes]] | publisher = Allen Lane |year= 2012 | isbn = 978-1-84614-446-2}} *{{cite book |first = Hugh | last = Johnson |author2=Robinson, Jancis | title = [[The World Atlas of Wine]] | publisher = Mitchell Beazley | edition = 7th | year = 2013 |isbn = 978-1-84533-301-0 }} *{{cite book| editor = Robinson, Jancis | title = [[The Oxford Companion to Wine]] | publisher = Oxford University Press | edition = 4th |year= 2015 | isbn = 978-0-19-870538-3 }} *{{cite book| first = Jancis | last = Robinson | title = Jancis Robinson's Wine Course | publisher = Abbeville Press Publishers | edition = 2nd |year= 2003 | isbn = 978-0-7892-0791-3}} *{{cite book| first = Jancis | last = Robinson | title = How to Taste Wine <small>''(UK)</small>;'' How to Taste <small>''(U.S.)''</small> | publisher = Conran Octopus/Simon & Schuster | year= 2008 | isbn = 978-1-84091-520-4}} *{{cite book| first = Jancis | last = Robinson | title = Confessions of a Wine Lover <small>''(UK)</small>;'' Tasting Pleasure <small>''(U.S.)''</small> | publisher = Penguin/Viking |year= 1997| isbn = 978-0-14-023529-6}} *{{cite book| first = Jancis | last = Robinson | title = Vines, Grapes and Wines | publisher = Mitchell Beazley | year= 1986 | isbn = 978-1-85732-999-5}}
==See also== *[[List of wine personalities]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.jancisrobinson.com/ Jancis Robinson's Purple Pages] * [https://www.ft.com/life-arts/jancis-robinson Jancis Robinson articles in ''Financial Times''] * [http://www.cityweekend.com.cn/shanghai/article/podcast-interview-and-live-blogging-jancis-robinson-writing-about-wine-impossible Podcast of Jancis Robinson discussing "Writing about wine" at the Shanghai International Literary Festival] * [http://aeyalgross.com/blog/?p=60515 Live blogging interview with Jancis Robinson] * [https://wineonsix.com/talking-with-jancis-robinson-about-wine-and-time/ Interview with Jancis Robinson]
{{Authority control}}

{{advertisement|date=September 2018}} {{BLP sources|date=November 2015}} {{Infobox person | name = Jericho Rosales | image = https://goo.gl/images/VoqH4G | birth_name = Jericho Vibar Rosales | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|mf=yes|1979|9|22}}{{cite web|url=https://familysearch.org/ark:/61903/3:1:3Q9M-CS71-WSH7-Y|title=Film # 007871517 Image Film # 007871517; ark:/61903/3:1:3Q9M-CS71-WSH7-Y|website=FamilySearch.org|accessdate=November 27, 2015}} | birth_place = [[Quezon City]], [[Philippines]] | agent = [[Star Magic]] (1997–2006; 2014–present)
[[Gary Valenciano|Manila Genesis]] (2006–2014) | spouse = {{marriage|[[Kim Jones (digital_creative)|Kim Jones]]|May 1, 2014}} | children = 1 | yearsactive = 1996–present | othername = Echo }} '''Jericho "Echo" Vibar Rosales''' (born September 22, 1979) is an entertainer from the Philippines. Primarily a film and television actor, "Echo" as is he known by his friends and fans, began his career by winning the Mr. Pogi ("Handsome") talent search on the noontime variety television show [[Eat Bulaga!|''Eat Bulaga!'']] His outstanding talent has secured an epic rise and an impressive portfolio of roles both on TV and in film, spanning over 20 years and a variety of genres, warranting the monicker, "Asia's Prince of Dramas."{{Cite web|url=https://starcinema.abs-cbn.com/2016/5/12/news/jericho-hailed-as-asia-s-prince-of-dramas-16476|title=Jericho hailed as Asia’s Prince of Dramas {{!}} Star Cinema|last=Admin|first=Star Cinema|website=STAR CINEMA|language=en-US|access-date=2018-09-05}} He, likewise, is a popular commercial endorser and brand advocate of various leading companies in the Philippines. When not in front of the camera, Rosales, among many other things, is a singer, songwriter, and performer with three solo albums to his credit. Currently he stars as Lino Bartolome in the hit ABS-CBN primetime soap, ''Halik'', alongside [[Yam Concepcion]], [[Sam Milby]], and [[Yen Santos]]. He is married to British-Filipina digital creative [[Kim Jones (digital creative)|Kim Jones.]] ==Career== {{BLP unsourced section|date=November 2015}} After winning the Mr. Pogi contest in ''[[Eat Bulaga]]'', Rosales became a regular host and performer in the variety show. His career took off when he was cast opposite actress [[Angelika dela Cruz]] in the top-rating primetime drama series ''[[Esperanza (Philippine TV series)|Esperanza]],'' and in the teen horror flick [[Oka Tokat|''Oka Tokat'']]''.'' Their tandem made its way to the big screen through the blockbuster horror movie [[Magandang Hatinggabi|''Magandang Hatinggabi'']]. But their tandem was cut short when Dela Cruz decided to transfer to [[ABS CBN]]'s rival network, [[GMA Network|GMA]]. Rosales has garnered international attention in the Asian, African, and Latin American television markets since his drama serious have been distributed in these regions. In countries such as Malaysia, China, Ghana,{{Cite web|url=https://www.philstar.com/cebu-entertainment/2007/03/23/391002/jericho-rosales-big-hit-ghana-africa|title=Jericho Rosales A Big Hit in Ghana, Africa {{!}} Philstar.com|website=philstar.com|access-date=2018-09-05}} Cambodia{{Cite web|url=https://starcinema.abs-cbn.com/2016/5/12/news/jericho-hailed-as-asia-s-prince-of-dramas-16476|title=Jericho hailed as Asia’s Prince of Dramas {{!}} Star Cinema|last=Admin|first=Star Cinema|website=STAR CINEMA|language=en-US|access-date=2018-09-05}}, Peru, Colombia, and many others, for his primetime soaps ''[[Pangako Sa 'Yo]]'' (2000-2002), ''[[Sana'y Wala Nang Wakas]]'' (2003-2004) and ''[[Dahil May Isang Ikaw]]'' (2009-2010), all co-starring Kristine Hermosa. Since its original release, ''[[Pangako Sa 'Yo]]'' has aired in over 20 foreign territories, with the Cambodian Television Network ordering a local remake in 2013.{{Cite news|url=https://news.abs-cbn.com/entertainment/05/25/15/watch-cambodian-remake-pangako-sa-yo|title=WATCH: Cambodian remake of 'Pangako Sa 'Yo'|last=News|first=ABS-CBN|work=ABS-CBN News|access-date=2018-09-05|language=en-US}} In Peru, Rosales is known for his role in the series ''[[Bridges of Love]] ("[[:es:Puentes_de_amor|Puentes de Amor"]]),'' the first Filipino drama to air in the country and the Latin American market.{{Cite web|url=https://starcinema.abs-cbn.com/2016/5/12/news/jericho-hailed-as-asia-s-prince-of-dramas-16476|title=Jericho hailed as Asia’s Prince of Dramas {{!}} Star Cinema|last=Admin|first=Star Cinema|website=STAR CINEMA|language=en-US|access-date=2018-09-05}} Similarly, ''[[The Legal Wife]]'' (2014)'','' which also stars [[Maja Salvador]] and [[Angel Locsin]], have gained much popularity in the African and Balkan regions.{{Cite web|url=https://starcinema.abs-cbn.com/2016/5/12/news/jericho-hailed-as-asia-s-prince-of-dramas-16476|title=Jericho hailed as Asia’s Prince of Dramas {{!}} Star Cinema|last=Admin|first=Star Cinema|website=STAR CINEMA|language=en-US|access-date=2018-09-05}} In 2006 he portrayed legendary Filipino boxing champion [[Manny Pacquiao]] in ''[[Pacquiao: The Movie|Pacquio: The Movie]],'' and bagged two Best Actor trophies for his work. He repeated this feat in 2008, when he won two more Best Actor awards for his role in the classic film ''[[Baler (film)|Baler]]'', opposite [[Anne Curtis]]. In 2012, Rosales played the lead role in ''[[Alagwa (film)|Alagwa]] (Breakaway,'' internationally), for which he won the which won Best Actor Trophy at the 36th [[Gawad Urian Award|Gawad Urian Awards]], one of the Philippines' most respected award-giving bodies. ''Alagwa'' garnered several accolades in film festivals around the world, most notably the Most Outstanding Achievement in Film Acting Award at the 2013 [[Newport Beach Film Festival]] in California; the Grand Jury Award - Best Narrative Feature in the 3rd Guam International Film Festival; Best Narrative in the [[Third World Independent Film Festival]]; and the First ASEAN International Film Festival.{{Cite news|url=https://news.abs-cbn.com/entertainment/10/01/13/jerichos-alagwa-wins-awards-guam-film-fest|title=Jericho's 'Alagwa' wins awards in Guam fIlm fest|last=News|first=ABS-CBN|work=ABS-CBN News|access-date=2018-09-05|language=en-US}} The following years found him in a string of Metro Manila Film Festival entries. In 2016, Rosales played Philippine national hero [[José Rizal|Jose Rizal]] in [[Bonifacio: Ang Unang Pangulo|''Bonifacio: Ang Unang Pangulo'']], which starred [[Robin Padilla]] as the eponymous character. His succeeding films were comedies, with rom-com [[WalangForever|''#WalangForever'']] in 2015, starring opposite [[Jennylyn Mercado]]; ''[[Ang Babae sa Septic Tank 2: ForeverIsNotEnough|Ang Babae Sa Septic Tank 2: #ForeverIsNotEnough]]'' in 2016 ''-'' sequel to Quantum Film's satirical 2011 hit starring [[Eugene Domingo]]; and then played opposite Bela Padilla in 2017's ''Luck At First Sight.'' In late 2017, he played Diego in surf romance film ''[[Siargao (film)|Siargao]]'', directed by [[Paul Soriano]]. Set in the eponymous Philippine island, he co-stars [[Erich Gonzales]] and [[Jasmine Curtis-Smith]]. Outside of film, Rosales has forged a music career which features his strengths as a lyricist, songwriter, and singer. He has released three full-length albums to his credit, and several music awards including ''Song of the Year Award'' for [[Pusong Ligaw (song)|"''Pusong Ligaw."'']] Other songs he has produced and co-written became theme songs of several of his television shows, including ''[[Green Rose (Philippine TV series)|Green Rose]], [[Dahil Sa Pag-ibig|Dahil sa Pag-Ibig]] (Because of Love)'' and ''[[I Dare You (Philippine TV series)|I Dare You]].'' ==Personal life== Rosales was born in [[Quezon City]], but was raised in Bula, [[Camarines Sur]]{{cite news|url=http://sports.inquirer.net/sportsbuzz/sportsbuzz/view/20090511-204427/Jericho_Rosales_bares_his_brand_of_fitness|accessdate=February 24, 2015|title=Jericho Rosales bares his brand of fitness|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150224042732/http://sports.inquirer.net/sportsbuzz/sportsbuzz/view/20090511-204427/Jericho_Rosales_bares_his_brand_of_fitness|archivedate=February 24, 2015|df=}} where he learned to speak [[Rinconada Bikol]]. In 2000, Rosales was linked to former model Kai Palomares, with whom he has a son, Santino "Saint" Palomares Rosales.{{citation needed|date=December 2015}} He married [[Kim Jones (digital creative)|Kim Jones]] in a beach wedding ceremony in [[Boracay]] on May 1, 2014.{{cite news|last1=Rañoa-Bismark|first1=Maridol|title=Jericho, Kim exchange vows in beach wedding|url=https://ph.celebrity.yahoo.com/news/jericho--kim-exchange-vows-in-beach-wedding-102843256.html|accessdate=June 30, 2014|work=Yahoo! {{Infobox character | colour = | name = | series = | image = Titor insignia.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = John Titor's purported military insignia | info-hdr = | noinfo = | fullname = John | nickname = Titor | alias = TimeTravel_0 | occupation = Alleged time traveler
Military soldier | affiliation = | title = | nationality = American }} '''John Titor''' is a name used on several [[Bulletin board system|bulletin boards]] during 2000 and 2001 by a poster claiming to be an American military [[time travel]]er from 2036.{{cite web|url=http://johntitor.com/Pages/Story.html|title=The John Titor Story|work=johntitor.com}}{{cite book|last=Scott|first=Alwyn|title=The nonlinear universe: chaos, emergence, life|year=26 Sep 2007|publisher=Springer|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=c91SqmJteo8C&lpg=PA121&ots=sMCm5rvTi9&pg=PA121#v=onepage&q&f=false|isbn=978-3-540-34152-9|page=121}} Titor made numerous vague and specific predictions regarding calamitous events in 2004 and beyond, including a nuclear war, none of which came true. Subsequent closer examination of Titor's assertions provoked widespread skepticism. Inconsistencies in his explanations, the uniform inaccuracy of his predictions, and a private investigator's findings all led to the general impression that the entire episode was an elaborate [[hoax]]. A 2009 investigation concluded that Titor was likely the creation of Larry Haber, a [[Florida]] entertainment lawyer, along with his brother Morey, a computer scientist.Who was John Titor, the time traveler who came from 2036 to warn us of a nuclear war? [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/science/11945420/Who-was-John-Titor-the-time-traveller-who-came-from-2036-to-warn-us-of-a-nuclear-war.html Telegraph.co.uk], retrieved April 22, 2016. == Titor's posts == The first posts using John Titor's military symbol appeared on the ''Time Travel Institute'' forums on November 2, 2000, under the name ''TimeTravel_0''.[https://timetravelinstitute.github.io/TTI-Archive//threads/time-travel-paradoxes.943/#post-9496 The original John Titor thread] At that time the name "John Titor" was not being used. The posts discussed time travel in general, the first one being the "six parts" description of what a time machine would need to have to work (see below) and responses to questions about how such a machine would work. Early messages tended to be short. A second thread was also made due to shortcomings in the forum software at the time.https://timetravelinstitute.github.io/TTI-Archive/threads/topics-limited-to-11-pages.1016/ John Titor's second thread The name "John Titor" was not introduced until January 2001, when TimeTravel_0 began posting at the [[Art Bell]] BBS Forums (which required a name or [[pseudonym]] for every account). The Titor posts ended in late March 2001. Around 2003, various websites reproduced Titor's posts, re-arranging them into narratives. Not all refer to the original dates posted.{{cite web|url=http://www.johntitor.com|title=John Titor – Time Traveler|accessdate=2007-03-15}} [[File:IBM 5100 - MfK Bern.jpg|thumb|right|IBM 5100 computer]] In his online postings, Titor claimed to be an American soldier from 2036, based in [[Tampa, Florida]]. He was assigned to a governmental time-travel project, and sent back to 1975 to retrieve an [[IBM 5100]] computer, which he said was needed to [[debug]] various legacy computer programs in 2036 – a possible reference to the [[UNIX]] [[year 2038 problem]]. The IBM 5100 runs the [[APL (programming language)|APL]] and [[BASIC]] programming languages. Titor said he had been selected for this mission specifically, given that his paternal grandfather was directly involved with the assembly and programming of the 5100.{{cite news|url=http://www.postbulletin.com/tangent-the-time-warp/article_c762cd83-e010-5b35-9362-519c8a7924fc.html|title=TANGENT The time warp|last=Stephenson|first=Patrick|work=[[Post-Bulletin]]|date=December 4, 2004|accessdate=August 6, 2018}} In support of this, he described unpublicized features of the 5100, leading to assumptions that a computer scientist was behind the postings. Titor claimed to be on a stopover in the year 2000 for "personal reasons", to collect pictures lost in the (future) civil war and to visit his family, of whom he spoke often. Titor also said he had been, for a few months, trying to alert anyone that would listen about the threat of [[Creutzfeldt–Jakob disease]] spread through beef products and about the possibility of civil war within the United States. When questioned about them by an online subscriber, Titor also expressed an interest in mysteries such as [[UFO]]s, which remained unexplained in his time. Titor suggested that UFOs and [[Extraterrestrial life|extraterrestrials]] might be travelers from much further into the future than his own time, with superior time machines. === Time machine === Titor described his time machine on several occasions. In an early post, he described it as a "stationary mass, temporal displacement unit powered by two top-spin, dual positive singularities", producing a "standard off-set [[Frank J. Tipler|Tipler]] sinusoid". The earliest post was more explicit, saying it contained the following: * Two magnetic housing units for the dual micro singularities * An electron injection [[manifold]] to alter mass and gravity of the micro [[Gravitational singularity|singularities]] * A cooling and [[X-ray]] venting system * Gravity sensors, or a variable gravity lock * Four main [[cesium clock]]s * Three main computer units According to the posts, the device was installed in the rear of a 1967 [[Chevrolet Corvette]] convertible{{cite web|url=https://newrepublic.com/article/116091/physicists-searched-internet-time-travelers|title=Two Physicists are Looking for Time Travelers on Facebook|last=Steadman|first=Ian|work=[[The New Republic]]|date=January 3, 2014|accessdate=August 6, 2018}} and later mentioned a 1987 truck having four-wheel drive. Titor shared several scans of the manual of a "C204 Time Displacement Unit" with diagrams and schematics and posted some photographs of the device installed in the car.{{Cite web|url=https://www.bibliotecapleyades.net/ciencia/time_travel/johntitor03.htm|title=John Titor's Time Machine|website=www.bibliotecapleyades.net|access-date=2018-08-12}} === Predictions === Although invoking the [[Multiverse#Level III: Many-worlds interpretation of quantum mechanics|many-worlds interpretation of quantum mechanics]], whereby events from his timeline may differ from our own, Titor also expressed assurance that the differences were minimal. As such, his descriptions have been interpreted as predictions and compared with historical events since 2001. The most immediate of Titor's predictions was of an [[Second American Revolution|upcoming civil war]] in the United States having to do with "order and rights".John Titor, 2/27/01 17:25 He described it as beginning in 2004,John Titor, 2/1/01 8:36 with [[civil unrest]] surrounding the [[United States presidential election, 2004|presidential election of that year]]. This civil conflict that he characterized as "having a [[Waco Siege|Waco]] type event every month that steadily gets worse" would be "pretty much at everyone's doorstep" and erupt by 2008. As a result of the war, the United States would split into five regions based on various factors and differing military objectives. This civil war, according to Titor, would end in 2015 with a brief but intense [[World War III]]. Titor refers to the exchange as "N Day". [[Washington, D.C.]] and [[Jacksonville, Florida]] are specifically mentioned as being hit. After the war, [[Omaha, Nebraska|Omaha]], [[Nebraska]] would be the new U.S. capital. Titor was vague as to the exact motivations and causes for World War III. At one point, he characterized the hostilities as being led by "border clashes and overpopulation".John Titor, 2/8/01 9:40 He also pointed to the contemporary conflict between Arabs and Israel as not a cause, but rather a milestone that precedes a World War III. Titor claimed that as a 13-year-old in 2011, he joined the Fighting Diamondbacks, a shotgun infantry unit in Florida, for at least four years. In other posts, he described himself as hiding from the war. Titor claimed that the "Everett–Wheeler model of quantum physics", better known as the [[many-worlds interpretation]], was correct. According to Titor, this caused a new timestream to form because of his time travel. This gives his predictions the ability to stand up to scrutiny when they fail to pass, since believers can say that the events were averted by Titor's postings. == Criticism and discussion == ''[[The New Republic]]'' called Titor the most famous of several internet forum posters who claimed to be time travelers. An Italian television program, ''Voyager – Ai confini della conoscenza'', aired the results of an investigation of John Titor on May 19, 2008. Private investigator Mike Lynch found no registry evidence, past or present, of any individual named John Titor. He did, however, identify the John Titor Foundation, a for-profit company formed on September 16, 2003, with no office or address other than a rented post box in [[Kissimmee, Florida]]. An IP address connected with Titor also geolocated to Kissimmee.{{cite web|url=http://www.voyager.rai.it/category/0,1067207,239-1078499,00.html |title=Rai.it – Voyager – Ai confini della conoscenza |publisher=Voyager |date= |accessdate=2010-09-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722050956/http://www.voyager.rai.it/category/0%2C1067207%2C239-1078499%2C00.html |archivedate=2011-07-22 |df= }} In 2009, a report by John Hughston of the Hoax Hunter website named Larry Haber, a Florida entertainment lawyer, as the CEO of the foundation.{{Cite web|url=http://hoaxhunter.blogspot.com/2009/02/john-titor-aka-razimus-report_13.html|title=JOHN TITOR A.K.A. RAZIMUS REPORT:|website=hoaxhunter.blogspot.com|access-date=2018-09-15}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4fQ2s5seNrs|title=Smoking Gun Proof John Titor Is Morey Haber Hoax Hunter 2016 Documentary by John Razimus:|website=youtube.com|access-date=2018-09-15}} Lynch concluded that Haber and his brother Morey Haber, a computer scientist, were very likely the men behind John Titor, whom they actually introduced in 1998, accompanied by different predictions, including chaos due to the [[Y2K bug|Y2K]] "bug". John Hughston also reported that John Titor is a registered trademark with the United States Patent and Trademark Office. == In popular culture == * In 2004, the John Titor Foundation published a book, ''John Titor: A Time Traveler's Tale'' ({{ISBN|1-59196-436-9}}), discussing his claims; the book is now out of print. * In 2004, ''Time Traveler Zero'', a play based on the John Titor story, was staged in the United States.[http://cyburbiaproductions.com/Productions/Time_traveler.html Time Traveler Zero Zero] * The 2009 visual novel ''[[Steins;Gate]]'', which was adapted into an anime in 2011, includes references to John Titor.{{cite web|url=https://www.rockpapershotgun.com/2018/03/25/steinsgate-gets-remaster-with-additional-stories/|title=Steins;Gate gets remaster with additional stories|last=Wilbur|first=Brock|work=[[Rock, Paper, Shotgun]]|date=March 25, 2018|accessdate=August 6, 2018}} * Titor is briefly mentioned in [[Graham McNeil]]'s [[Warhammer 40,000]] novel ''The Crimson King''. * John Titor is mentioned during ''Game Theory: How Zelda Breath of the Wild SOLVES The Zelda Timeline!''. ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == {{Commons category|John Titor}} * [https://timetravelinstitute.com/threads/time-travel-paradoxes.943/#post-9496 The original John Titor thread on Time Travel Institute] * [https://timetravelinstitute.com/threads/topics-limited-to-11-pages.1016/ John Titor's second thread on Time Travel Institute] * [http://h2g2.com/approved_entry/A6345407 John Titor: a Time Traveller From The Year 2036?] * [http://www.nicolabattista.it/is-john-titor-an-upcoming-disney-franchise.html Is John Titor an upcoming Disney franchise?] {{Time travel}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Titor, John}} [[Category:2036]] [[Category:Internet memes]] [[Category:Unidentified people]] [[Category:Usenet people]]

==Angela== '''Angela Logan Rummans''' (born March 23, 1992), 26, is a fitness model from [[Playa Vista, Los Angeles|Playa Vista, California]]. Originally from [[Hilton Head Island, South Carolina|Hilton Head, South Carolina]], she describes herself as spontaneous, scheming, and headstrong, and enjoys beach volleyball, spearfishing, and oil painting.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cbs.com/shows/big_brother/photos/1008403/meet-the-houseguests-on-big-brother-season-20/130819/angela-rummans/|title=Angela Rummans|publisher=CBS|accessdate=18 June 2018}}</ref> On Day 44, Angela won HOH. On Day 45, Angela nominated Rockstar and Scottie for eviction. On Day 46, Angela won the POV. On Day 48, Angela chose to use the POV on Tyler to remove him from the block and she named Bayleigh as the replacement nominee. On Day 52, Angela was nominated alongside Kaycee by Haleigh, the HOH. On Day 55, Tyler used the Veto to remove Angela from the block in which Haleigh, the HOH, named Kaycee as the replacement nominee in Angela's place. On Day 65, Angela won her second HOH of the season, becoming the first houseguest to win two HOH competitions this season. On Day 66, she nominated Faysal and Haleigh for eviction. On Day 86, She won her second POV, she chose to remove JC from eviction. On Day 86, she won her third HOH. On Day 87, she nominated JC and Sam for eviction.On Day 91, she was nominated by JC alongside Tyler for eviction. She has shown feelings for and eventually got into a showmance with Tyler. On Day 92, Angela was evicted by Kaycee (the sole voting Houseguest in this particular eviction), becoming the eighth member of the jury, and the final Houseguest to be evicted prior to finale night. Angela ultimately voted for Tyler to win Big Brother.
Both Angela and her showmance partner and current boyfriend Tyler have continued their romantic relationship outside of the Big Brother house. On October 1, 2018, Angela announced on her Instagram that both she and Tyler have officially begun living together.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.instagram.com/p/BoaTHgmnXd-/|title='Big Brother 20' Angela Rummans instagram||accessdate=4 Oct 2018}}</ref> They have both been active on social media post-Big Brother.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.instagram.com/angelarummans|title=Angela Rummans (@angelarummans) on Instagram||accessdate=4 Oct 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.instagram.com/tylercrispen2|title=Tyler Crispen (@tylercrispen2) on Instagram||accessdate=4 Oct 2018}}</ref>
==Bayleigh== '''Bayleigh Amethyst Dayton''' (born May 25, 1993), 25, is a flight attendant from [[Atlanta|Atlanta, Georgia]]. Originally from [[Lee's Summit, Missouri]], she describes herself as engulfing, adventurous, and unpredictable, and enjoys yoga, binge-watching random TV shows and [[Marvel Cinematic Universe|Marvel]] movies, and traveling.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cbs.com/shows/big_brother/photos/1008403/meet-the-houseguests-on-big-brother-season-20/130813/bayleigh-dayton/|title=Bayleigh Dayton|publisher=CBS|accessdate=18 June 2018}}</ref> She was the first African-American woman to become [[Miss Missouri USA]] and placed in the top ten and won Miss Congeniality at [[Miss USA 2017]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://rollingout.com/2016/10/01/meet-1st-black-miss-missouri-usa-bayleigh-dayton/|title=Meet the 1st Black Miss Missouri USA, Bayleigh Dayton|date=1 October 2016|publisher=Rolling Out}}</ref><ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=http://www.kansascity.com/news/local/article104637331.html#storylink=cpy|title=Lee’s Summit woman becomes first African-American Miss Missouri USA|last=Porter|first=Toriano|date=28 September 2016|newspaper=The Kansas City Star|access-date=8 February 2017|work=|via=}}</ref> In Week 3, Bayleigh won the Identity Theft power app as a reward for being the Top Trending HouseGuest that week. On Day 37, Bayleigh won HOH. On Day 38, she nominated Rachel and Brett for eviction. On Day 48, Angela named Bayleigh as the replacement nominee after using the POV to remove Tyler from the block. On Day 51, by the vote of 6-1, Bayleigh became the sixth houseguest evicted and become the first member of the Jury. On Day 72, she competed against Rockstar, Scottie and Faysal in the Battle Back competition, in which the winner would re-enter the House with a second shot to win the game. She was ultimately unsuccessful in this bid, and remained on the jury. Bayleigh voted for Kaycee to win.
After she cast her vote in the finale, Bayleigh received a marriage proposal by Swaggy C, which she accepted. A few days after the finale, Bayleigh revealed on YouTube that she had gotten pregnant with Swaggy C's baby during their time together in the Big Brother house, but that she went on to experience a miscarriage in the jury house.<ref>{{cite web|title=A Swayleigh Pregnancy Talk|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OAgJHQobFVg|publisher=YouTube|accessdate=28 September 2018}}</ref>
==Brett== '''Brett William Robinson''' (born January 15, 1993), 25, is a cybersecurity engineer from [[Charlestown, Boston|Charlestown, Massachusetts]]. Originally from [[Oakdale, Connecticut]], he describes himself as vehement, riveting, and trophy, and enjoys working out, home repair, and snowboarding.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cbs.com/shows/big_brother/photos/1008403/meet-the-houseguests-on-big-brother-season-20/130818/brett-robinson/|title=Brett Robinson|publisher=CBS|accessdate=18 June 2018}}</ref> On Day 24, he was nominated for eviction alongside Winston by Scottie. On Day 38, Brett was nominated alongside Rachel by Bayleigh (the HOH). On Day 59, he was nominated for eviction alongside Scottie by Faysal. He later won the POV and subsequently vetoed himself off of the block, in which Kaycee was nominated by Faysal in Brett's place. On Day 86, Angela used the Veto on JC and removed him from the block in which Tyler, the HOH, put Brett up as the replacement nominee. Brett was evicted with a 3-0 vote and became the sixth member of the Jury. Brett voted for Tyler to win Big Brother. As the America's Favorite Houseguest award was being announced, he was revealed to be one of the top three votegetters, but lost the contest to Tyler.
==Faysal== '''Faysal Shawn "Fessy" Shafaat''' (born October 17, 1991), 26, is a substitute teacher from [[Orlando, Florida]]. He describes himself as a joker, hilarious, and confident, and enjoys music, food, and working out or playing sports.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cbs.com/shows/big_brother/photos/1008403/meet-the-houseguests-on-big-brother-season-20/130821/faysal-shafaat/|title=Faysal Shafaat|publisher=CBS|accessdate=18 June 2018}}</ref> On Day 10, Faysal won the first POV of the season, but ultimately opted against using the POV. In Week One, he was deemed to be the least trending Houseguest, and was thus required to choose a Crap App, in which he selected Hamazon. On Day 31, Faysal won his second POV of the season. He took Haleigh off of the block, and HOH Sam nominated Rockstar in her place. On Day 58, he won HOH, and on the following day (Day 59), nominated Brett and Scottie to be marked for eviction. Upon Brett winning the POV and removing himself from the block, Faysal opted to place Kaycee up as the replacement nominee. On Day 66, Faysal was nominated alongside Haleigh by Angela, the HOH. On Day 72, he was evicted from the Big Brother house on a 4-1 vote, with only Sam voting to evict Haleigh. Faysal then competed in the Battle Back competition, in which he was defeated alongside Bayleigh and Rockstar by Scottie. At the time of eviction, he became the fourth member of the jury, but after the Battle Back competition, he became the third member of the jury by virtue of Scottie re-entering the House. Faysal voted for Kaycee to win Big Brother. During the finale he confirmed that himself and fellow houseguest Haleigh were in a relationship.
==Haleigh== '''Haleigh Falyn Broucher''' (born January 23, 1997), 21, is a college student from [[College Station, Texas]]. Originally from [[Village Mills, Texas|Village Mills]], she describes herself as classic, cautious, and contagious, and enjoys working out, traveling, and taking a good, long nap.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cbs.com/shows/big_brother/photos/1008403/meet-the-houseguests-on-big-brother-season-20/130810/haleigh-broucher/|title=Haleigh Broucher|publisher=CBS|accessdate=18 June 2018}}</ref> She is the youngest houseguest this season. In Week Three, she was deemed to be the least trending houseguest, and was required to select a Crap App, choosing "Read It!" She was nominated for eviction by Sam on Day 31, alongside Kaitlyn. However when Faysal won the POV, he took her off of the block, and HOH Sam nominated Rockstar in her place. On Week Six, she won the H@cker Competition and was required to choose a Houseguest of her choice to replace someone on the chopping block. She chose Tyler to go on the block and saved Scottie. She also chose Kaycee to play in the Veto competition. On Day 51, Haleigh won the Head of Household competition. On Day 52, she nominated Angela and Kaycee. On Day 55, Haleigh named Kaycee as the replacement nominee after Tyler used the Veto on Angela. On Day 66, Haleigh was nominated alongside Faysal by Angela, the HOH. On Day 73, Haleigh was nominated alongside Scottie for eviction by Tyler, the HOH. On Day 80, Haleigh was nominated alongside Sam by Kaycee, the HOH. On Day 86, Haleigh was evicted by a 4-0 vote and became the fifth member of the jury. Haleigh voted for Tyler to win Big Brother, being the only member of her alliance in Jury to vote in his favor. As the award for America's Favorite Houseguest was announced, it was revealed that Haleigh finished in the top three in votes received for the award, but lost the contest to Tyler.
==JC== '''Joseph Charles "JC" Mounduix''' (born February 6, 1993), 25, is a professional dancer from [[West Hollywood, California]]. Raised in [[Miami|Miami, Florida]], he describes himself as outgoing, honest, and eccentric, and enjoys going to the gym, watching movies, and going to theme parks. <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.cbs.com/shows/big_brother/photos/1008403/meet-the-houseguests-on-big-brother-season-20/130817/jc-monduix/%7Ctitle=JC%20Monduix|title=Big Brother photos|work=CBS|access-date=2018-09-09}}</ref> On Day 86, JC was nominated alongside Sam by Tyler, the HOH during the second portion of the Double Eviction (JC's nomination ensured that all Houseguests this season have since been on the block at one point or another in the season). JC was saved from eviction by Angela using the Power of Veto, in which Brett went up in his place and was evicted. On day 91, JC won the Head of Household competition and nominated Tyler and Angela for eviction. On Day 99, he was evicted by Kaycee (the Final HOH casts the final vote to evict), finishing in third place and became the ninth and final member of the Jury. JC voted for Tyler to win Big Brother.
==Kaitlyn== '''Kaitlyn Sara Herman''' (born April 24, 1994), 24, is a life coach from [[Encino, Los Angeles|Encino, California]]. Originally from [[Plainview, New York]], she describes herself as personable, intuitive, and dramatic, and enjoys taking [[Barre (exercise)|Pure Barre]] classes, meditation, and watching reality television.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cbs.com/shows/big_brother/photos/1008403/meet-the-houseguests-on-big-brother-season-20/130814/kaitlyn-herman/|title=Kaitlyn Herman|publisher=CBS|accessdate=18 June 2018}}</ref> On Day 16, Kaitlyn won HOH. On Day 17, she nominated Scottie and Winston for eviction. On Day 20, Kaitlyn named Swaggy C as the replacement nominee after POV winner Tyler removed Scottie from the block. On Day 31, she was nominated for eviction (alongside Haleigh) by Sam (the HOH). On Day 37, Kaitlyn was evicted by a vote of 9-1. Due to Sam's B.B. Power App called Bonus Life, she was given the chance to return to the game. However, she failed to complete the task and her eviction was sealed.
==Kaycee== '''Kaycee Noelle Clark''' (born December 26, 1987), 30, is a pro-football player for the [[San Diego Surge]] and is from [[Tempe, Arizona]]. Originally from [[San Diego|San Diego, California]], she describes herself as fun, positive, and athletic, and enjoys playing sports, working out, and personal development.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cbs.com/shows/big_brother/photos/1008403/meet-the-houseguests-on-big-brother-season-20/130811/kaycee-clark/|title=Kaycee Clark|publisher=CBS|accessdate=18 June 2018}}</ref> On Day 52, Kaycee was nominated alongside Angela by Haleigh, the HOH. On the same day, she won the H@cker Competition. She removed herself from the block and chose Rockstar as the replacement. On Day 53, she chose Tyler to play in the Veto competition. When Tyler won the Veto he used it on Angela, then Haleigh nominated Kaycee again as the replacement nominee. She was nominated again the following week as a replacement nominee when Brett won Veto and used it upon himself, landing on the block against Scottie. On Day 67, Kaycee won the Veto. On Day 69, Kaycee decided to not use the veto, leaving Angela's nominations of Faysal and Haleigh intact. On Day 76, Kaycee chose not to use the Veto, keeping Tyler’s nominations of Scottie and Haleigh intact. On Day 79, Kaycee won HOH. On Day 80, Kaycee nominated Haleigh and Sam. During the same week, Kaycee won her third consecutive Power of Veto, tying the all-time consecutive veto wins record. She ultimately opted not to use the Veto, leaving Haleigh and Sam to face that weeks eviction vote (which would turn out to be the first eviction of that evening's Double Eviction). Kaycee won her fourth veto during Week 12, and again opted not to use the veto, leaving Angela's (the week's HOH) nominations of JC and Sam intact. On Day 91, Kaycee won her fifth veto of the season (which also happened to be the final Power of Veto competition for the summer), tying the all time record of veto wins in a season. As she was the sole houseguest not on the block or HOH that week, the Veto was not used. Kaycee thus held the balance of power that week as she held the sole vote to evict, opting to evict Angela. On Day 99, Kaycee won the Final HOH and chose to evict JC, taking Tyler to the Final 2. Kaycee won Big Brother 20 by a vote of 5-4 over Tyler, and became the first openly lesbian winner of Big Brother.
