==Rachel== '''Rachel Elizabeth Swindler''' (born July 15, 1988), 29, is an entertainer from [[Las Vegas|Las Vegas, Nevada]]. Originally from [[Myrtle Beach, South Carolina]], she describes herself as sarcastic, loyal, and passionate, and enjoys live music, attending sporting events, and working out.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cbs.com/shows/big_brother/photos/1008403/meet-the-houseguests-on-big-brother-season-20/130822/rachel-swindler/|title=Rachel Swindler|publisher=CBS|accessdate=18 June 2018}}</ref> In Week Two, Rachel was deemed to be the least trending houseguest, and thus had to select a Crap App, in which she opted for "Yell!" On Day 38, Rachel was nominated for eviction alongside Brett by Bayleigh. On Day 44, Rachel was evicted by a 5-4 vote and became the fifth houseguest evicted from the game, and the final houseguest to be voted out prior to the beginning of the Jury stage.
==Rockstar== '''Angela Brooke "Angie" Lantry''' (born June 22, 1983), 34, is a stay-at-home mom from [[Columbia, Maryland]]. Thoroughout the season, she was referred to by her nickname '''Rockstar''' to avoid confusion with fellow HouseGuest Angela Rummans. She describes herself as eclectic, entertaining, and magical, and enjoys reading, writing, and dancing under the moonlight around a fire to fierce drum beats.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cbs.com/shows/big_brother/photos/1008403/meet-the-houseguests-on-big-brother-season-20/130816/angie-rockstar-lantry/|title=Angie "Rockstar" Lantry|publisher=CBS|accessdate=18 June 2018}}</ref> She is a Pagan [[witch]].<ref>https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/lists/big-brother-20-cast-interviews-1121206/item/sam-bledsoe-big-brother-20-cast-interview-1121362</ref> She got annoyed when Brett came after her on her daughter's birthday. On Day 34, Sam, the HOH, put Rockstar up as the replacement nominee after POV winner Faysal took Haleigh off the block. On Day 45, Rockstar was nominated alongside Scottie for eviction. On Day 52 Rockstar was nominated by the hacker, Kaycee for eviction. On Day 58 she was evicted by a vote of 5-1, making her the seventh person to be evicted from the big brother house and the second member of the jury. On Day 72, she competed against Bayleigh, Scottie and Faysal in the Battle Back competition for the opportunity to re-enter the House for a second shot to win the game. She ultimately was unsuccessful in the competition, and remained on the jury. Rockstar cast her vote for Kaycee to win Big Brother.
==Sam== '''Samantha Marie "Sam" Bledsoe''' (born June 7, 1991), 27, is a welder from [[Stuarts Draft, Virginia]]. She describes herself as multifaceted, charming, and charismatic, and enjoys making, building and creating things, fishing, swimming, kayaking, and dancing.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cbs.com/shows/big_brother/photos/1008403/meet-the-houseguests-on-big-brother-season-20/130809/sam-bledsoe/|title=Sam Bledsoe|publisher=CBS|accessdate=18 June 2018}}</ref> She was nominated alongside Steve for eviction by HOH Tyler. She won the first B.B. App power called Bonus Life. On Day 30, she won her first Head of Household competition, nominating Kaitlyn and Haleigh for eviction on Day 31. After Faysal won POV and saved Haleigh, she nominated Rockstar as the replacement nominee. On Day 80, Sam was nominated for eviction alongside Haleigh by HOH Kaycee. On Day 86, Sam was nominated alongside JC by Tyler, the HOH, and survived eviction against Brett in the double eviction later that day. She was nominated again by Angela the following week alonside JC, and was evicted on Day 91 by a 2-0 vote, becoming the seventh member of the Jury of Nine. She cast her jury vote for Kaycee to win.
==Scottie== '''Scott Edward "Scottie" Salton''' (born January 10, 1992), 26, is a shipping manager from [[Chicago|Chicago, Illinois]]. Originally from [[Shorewood, Illinois|Shorewood]], he describes himself as energetic, odd, and persistent, and enjoys disc golf, [[CrossFit]], and watching movies.<ref> {{cite web|url=https://www.cbs.com/shows/big_brother/photos/1008403/meet-the-houseguests-on-big-brother-season-20/130820/scottie-salton/|title=Scottie Salton|publisher=CBS|accessdate=18 June 2018}}</ref> On Day 17, Scottie was nominated for eviction alongside Winston by HOH Kaitlyn. On Day 20, POV winner Tyler removed Scottie from the block with Kaitlyn naming Swaggy C as a replacement nominee. On Day 23, Scottie won HOH. He nominated Brett and Winston for eviction on Day 24. On Day 25, Scottie won the POV, and chose not to use the POV on Day 27, leaving his original nominations of Brett and Winston intact. On Day 59, he was nominated alongside Brett by the HOH of the week, Faysal. On Day 65, Scottie was evicted by a 6-0 vote and became the third member of the Jury.
On Day 72, after winning the Jury Battle Back, Scottie returned to the game. On Day 73, Scottie was nominated alongside Haleigh for eviction by Tyler, the HOH. On Day 79, Scottie was evicted by a 5-0 vote and became the fourth member of the Jury. Scottie cast his vote for Kaycee to win Big Brother.
==Steve== '''Stephen Russell "Steve" Arienta''' (born May 2, 1978), 40, is a former undercover cop from [[Wanaque, New Jersey]]. Originally from [[Parsippany, New Jersey|Parsippany]], he describes himself as stubborn, competitive, and funny, and enjoys motorcycle riding, fishing, and playing golf.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cbs.com/shows/big_brother/photos/1008403/meet-the-houseguests-on-big-brother-season-20/|title=Steve Arienta|publisher=CBS|accessdate=18 June 2018}}</ref> He is the oldest houseguest this season. Steve was nominated alongside Sam by HOH Tyler. On Day 16, he was evicted by a vote of 7-6.
==Swaggy C== '''Christopher Jordan "Chris" Williams''' (born February 17, 1995), 23, is a day trader from [[Bridgeport, Connecticut]]. Throughout his time in the house, he went by the name '''Swaggy C''' and also brought a large amount of T-shirts printed with the aforementioned moniker. He describes himself as outspoken, rebellious, and analytical, and enjoys playing basketball, working out, traveling, and entertaining people on his [[Snapchat]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cbs.com/shows/big_brother/photos/1008403/meet-the-houseguests-on-big-brother-season-20/130823/chris-swaggy-c-williams/|title=Chris "Swaggy C" Williams|publisher=CBS|accessdate=18 June 2018}}</ref> On Day 22, Chris was the replacement nominee alongside Winston by HOH Kaitlyn after POV holder Tyler chose to take Scottie off the block. On Day 23, by the vote of 8-4, Chris became the second houseguest evicted from the ''Big Brother'' house. Shortly after the Jury voted for the winner of Big Brother, Swaggy C crossed the stage to the Jury to Bayleigh and after a short speech, he proposed to Bayleigh. His proposal was accepted, and the two became engaged.
==Tyler== '''Tyler Ross Crispen''' (born February 17, 1995), 23, is a lifeguard from [[Hilton Head Island, South Carolina|Hilton Head, South Carolina]]. Originally from [[Rossford, Ohio]], he describes himself as resilient, charismatic, and questionable, and enjoys working out, going to the beach, and surfing.<ref> {{cite web|url=https://www.cbs.com/shows/big_brother/photos/1008403/meet-the-houseguests-on-big-brother-season-20/130812/tyler-crispen/|title=Tyler Crispen|publisher=CBS|accessdate=18 June 2018}}</ref> He is the youngest male houseguest this season. On Day 3, Tyler became the first HOH of the season. He nominated Sam and Steve for eviction. On Day 18, Tyler won POV. On Day 22, Tyler decided to use the POV to take Scottie off the block with HOH Kaitlyn nominating Swaggy C as the replacement nominee in Scottie's place. In Week 2, Tyler won the second B.B. App Power called The Cloud. The Cloud gives Tyler the power to be immune from nominations during either a nomination ceremony or a POV ceremony and he has eight weeks to exercise the power. On Day 39, Tyler won his second POV. On Day 41, he chose not use the POV, keeping Bayliegh's nominations of Brett and Rachel intact. On Day 45, Tyler was nominated next to Rockstar after Haleigh, who won the H@cker Competition, removed Scottie from the block and replaced him with Tyler. On Day 48, Angela used the POV on Tyler and removed him from the block, replacing his nomination spot with Bayleigh. On Day 53, Tyler won the POV, his second one of the season. On Day 55, Tyler used the POV to remove Angela from the block and Haleigh (the HOH) named Kaycee as the replacement nominee. On Day 72, Tyler won his second HOH. On Day 73, he nominated Scottie and Haleigh for eviction. His nominations remained intact as Kaycee opted not to use the veto. On Day 86, he won HOH for the third time, becoming the first houseguest this season to notch three HOH wins. As his third HOH was the second part of the Double Eviction, he shortly thereafter nominated JC and Sam for eviction. Tyler's nominations did change as Angela won and used the Power of Veto to remove JC from the block and Tyler then named Brett as the replacement nominee. On Day 91, Tyler was nominated for eviction (alongside Angela) by the HOH, JC. On Day 93, Tyler won Part 1 of the final HOH contest. Tyler lost by a lot of 5-4 to Kaycee, making him the runner up of the season. He won the America's Favorite Houseguest prize and was awarded $25,000.
Both Tyler and his showmance partner and current girlfriend Angela have continued their relationship outside of the Big Brother house. On October 1, 2018, Angela announced on her instagram that both her and Tyler have begun living together.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.instagram.com/p/BoaTHgmnXd-/|title='Big Brother 20' Angela Rummans instagram||accessdate=4 Oct 2018}}</ref> Both have become active on social media after the show.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.instagram.com/angelarummans|title=Angela Rummans (@angelarummans) on Instagram||accessdate=4 Oct 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.instagram.com/tylercrispen2|title=Tyler Crispen (@tylercrispen2) on Instagram||accessdate=4 Oct 2018}}</ref>
Prior to appearing on ''Big Brother'', Crispen had been a contestant on the second episode of ''[[TKO: Total Knock Out]]'', a CBS obstacle course game show that was taped back in May 2018. The episode aired in July 2018, while Crispen was still in the Big Brother house.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.realityblurred.com/realitytv/2018/07/bb20-tyler-crispen-tko-total-knock-out-same-time/|title=How is BB20’s Tyler Crispen on TKO: Total Knock Out tonight, too?|last=Dehnart|first=Andy|work=Reality Blurred|date=July 18, 2018|accessdate=August 11, 2018}}</ref>
==Winston== '''Winston Howard Hines''' (born February 13, 1990), 28, is a medical sales representative from [[Bowling Green, Kentucky]]. Originally from [[Somerset, Kentucky|Somerset]], he describes himself as active, ambitious, and passionate, and enjoys hiking, long walks or driving with his dog, working out, and watching movies.<ref> {{cite web|url=https://www.cbs.com/shows/big_brother/photos/1008403/meet-the-houseguests-on-big-brother-season-20/130815/winston-hines/|title=Winston Hines|publisher=CBS|accessdate=18 June 2018}}</ref> On Day 17, Winston was nominated alongside Scottie by HOH Kaitlyn. He was nominated a second time for eviction on Day 24 by Scottie, this time alongside Brett. On Day 30, Winston was evicted by a vote of 6-5, becoming the third houseguest to be evicted from the Big Brother house. He was the first houseguest to be nominated twice this season.

Borst-signature.png | signature_alt = | website = | footnotes = }} '''Lyle Benjamin Borst''' (24 November 1912 – 30 July 2002), nuclear physicist, inventor, worked with [[Enrico Fermi]] in Chicago, involved with the [[Manhattan District Project]], and worked with [[Ernest O. Wollan]] to conduct [[neutron scattering]] and [[neutron diffraction]] studies. ==Life and Times== Lyle Benjamin Borst was born on 24 November 1912 in Cook County at [[Chicago, Illinois]] the son of George William Borst aged 39 of Chicago, Illinois and Jennie Beveridge aged 26. Borst was married to Ruth Barbara Mayer Borst for 63 years and had 3 children, sons, John Benjamin and Stephen Lyle and daughter, Frances Elizabeth Wright including 7 grandchildren and 4 great grandchildren. He died at his home in [[Williamsville, New York]] on 30 July 2002.Wright, Frances Elizabeth. (2002). Dr. Lyle Benjamin Borst, 1912 – 2002, Professor of Physics at University of Buffalo, 1961-1983. University of Buffalo.O'Connor, Anahad. (12 August 2002). Lyle Benjamin Borst. New York Times.Moser, Whet. (16 August 2002). Physicist Borst dies at 89. The Chicago Maroon. The University of Chicago. Chicago, Illinois. ==Career== Borst attended the [[University of Illinois]] and received bachelor's and master's degrees. He attended the [[University of Chicago]] and was awarded a doctorate degree in [[chemistry]] in 1941.Borst, Lyle Benjamin. (1941). The Angular Distribution of Recoil Nuclei. II. Notes on the Deuteron Hydrogen-three Reaction (Doctoral dissertation, University of Chicago, Department of Chemistry.). Borst worked as a senior [[physicist]] on the [[Manhattan Project]] from 1943-1946 at the [[Clinton Engineering Works|Clinton Laboratories]] in [[Oak Ridge, Tennessee]]. In 1944 [[Ernest O. Wollan]] and Borst used [[neutron diffraction]] to produce "[[Diffraction topography|rocking curve]]s" for crystals of gypsum and [[sodium chloride]] (salt).Wollan, E. O. and Borst, L. B. (1945). Physics Section III Monthly Report for the Period Ending December 31, 1944. Metallurgical Project Report No. M-CP-2222. Clinton Laboratories. Oak Ridge, Tennessee, USA. 1945.Mason, T. E.; Gawne, T. J.; Nagler, S. E.; Nestor, M. B.; Carpenter, J. M. (2013). "The early development of neutron diffraction: Science in the wings of the Manhattan Project" (PDF). Acta Crystallographica Section A 69: 37–44. doi:10.1107/S0108767312036021 In 1946 [[Karl Z. Morgan]] and Borst at Oak Ridge develop a [[film badge]] to measure worker exposure to [[fast neutrons]].Morgan, K. Z. (1947). Health Physics and its control of radiation exposures at Clinton Laboratories. Technical Information Division, Oak Ridge Operations.Morgan, K. Z. (1947). Health physics and its control of radiation exposures at Clinton National Laboratory. Chem. Engineering News. 25, 3794. From 1946-1951 Borst was Chairman of the Department of Reactor Science and Engineering at [[Brookhaven National Laboratory]] and was responsible for the operation and oversight of the [[Brookhaven National Laboratory|Brookhaven Graphite Research Reactor]].Crease, Robert P. (1999). Making Physics: A Biography of Brookhaven National Laboratory, 1946-1972. University of Chicago Press. He played a key role in the design of the research reactor. Borst was at the [[University of Utah]] from 1951-1953 as Professor of Physics. From 1956-1961 he was Chairman of the Department of Physics at the College of Engineering at [[New York University]]. From 1961-1983 Borst was Professor of Physics at [[State University of New York]] in [[Buffalo, New York]] and was appointed [[Professor Emeritus]] in 1983. In 1969 he served as [[Master (college)|Master]] of Clifford Furnas College at the [[State University of New York at Buffalo]].Wright, Frances Elizabeth. (2002). Dr. Lyle Benjamin Borst, 1912 – 2002, Professor of Physics at University of Buffalo, 1961-1983. University of Buffalo.O'Connor, Anahad. (12 August 2002). Lyle Benjamin Borst. CONVERGENT NEUTRONIC REACTOR (No. CA 642347). "A convergatron-type neutron amplifier is designed in which a neutron flux is increased stage by stage, where each stage comprises a moderator region, a fuel region, and a thermal neutron absorber region. The amplifier may be modified to reduce the inherent feedback and to enhance the transparency to neutrons in the desired polarized direction. The modifications include inhomogeneous fuel distribution, oriented cavities in the fuel region, and arcuately bent cylinders in the moderator region." *Neutron amplifier. 2 October 1962.Borst, L. '''Mohammed Amin''' (born November 15, 1913) is an [[Egypt]]ian [[Boxing|boxer]] who competed in the [[1936 Summer Olympics]].
In 1936 he was eliminated in the second round of the [[Boxing at the 1936 Summer Olympics - Men's light heavyweight|light heavyweight class]] after losing his fight to [[Robey Leibbrandt]] of [[South Africa]].

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} [[Image:Dackestatyn Virserum 20060803.jpg|thumb|300 px|Statue of Nils Dacke in [[Virserum]]]] '''Nils Dacke''' was a [[Sweden|Swedish]] [[yeoman]] who was the leader of a mid-16th century peasant revolt in [[Småland]], southern [[Sweden]], called the [[Dacke War]] (Swedish: ''Dackefejden''), fought against the [[King of Sweden|Swedish king]] [[Gustav I]] [[Vasa family|Vasa]]. It was the most widespread and serious civil war in Swedish history and almost toppled the king.<ref>[http://www.tacitus.nu/svenskhistoria/kungar/vasa/gv-5.htm ''Den tyska perioden och Dackefejden'' (Tacitus.Nu)]</ref>
==Background== [[Gustav Vasa]] had come to power at the head of a [[peasant]] army in 1523. He had established Sweden's independence from [[Denmark]] and made Protestantism the national religion. Småland found itself on the border between Sweden and Denmark and was hard hit by Vasa's ban on cross-border trade. In addition, the heavyhanded way in which the church was reformed and the increasing tax burden led to much dissatisfaction among the poor peasants. Already in 1536, Nils Dacke was tried at a local court for killing a [[sheriff]]; according to court records he was fined 10 [[oxen]].
==The Dacke War== The uprising started in June 1542 with the assassination of more sheriffs and tax collectors. Gustav Vasa underestimated the military prowess of the peasants and sent his German [[mercenary|mercenaries]] to quell the revolt. The [[landsknecht]]s were, however, unsuited for battle in the rugged forests and suffered heavy losses. Dacke had devised defensive tactics that allowed the peasants to use their steel [[crossbow]]s with devastating effect. Dacke's successes helped spread the revolt over all the southern provinces of Sweden. The situation was so serious that the king was forced to sue for peace, and a one-year [[ceasefire]] was signed on 8 November. During the ceasefire, Dacke was the de facto ruler of most of southern Sweden and received offers of foreign support from the [[Elector Palatine]] [[Frederick II, Elector Palatine|Frederick II]] (who was the son-in-law of [[Christian II]] and claimed the Swedish throne) and Duke Albrecht of [[Mecklenburg]]. He reinstated the ceremonies of the Roman Catholic Church and reopened the cross-border trade in the areas under his control. With Danish support Gustav Vasa mounted an invasion of Mecklenburg which neutralised the German threat.
The king broke the ceasefire in January 1543 and sent a new and larger army into the rebellious area. Royal propaganda had been spread to win over the population and turn them against Dacke. Dacke himself had become overconfident after earlier successes and met the Royal army in a [[pitched battle]] in March. The trained soldiers fighting on their own terms shattered the peasant army, and Dacke was severely injured. After this defeat, the rebellion was effectively over and Dacke became an [[outlaw]].
==Death== [[File:NilsDackeshuvud.JPG|thumb|Nils Dacke´s severed head. Drawing by the 16th-century chronicler [[Joen Petri Klint]].]] Dacke was shot and killed in the high summer of 1543 in the forests which, at the time, surrounded the southeastern border between Sweden and Denmark (nowadays southern Swedish provinces Småland and [[Blekinge]]). According to contemporary sources, he had been injured in both legs by hits from the king's crossbows during the decisive battle a few months earlier, his forces had been routed, and he was likely trying to escape from the king's mercenaries. There is no doubt that he was killed on the spot.
Dacke was [[posthumous execution|executed posthumously]], quartered, and his limbs were sent for public display in larger communities that had supported him during the rebellion. Gustav Vasa ordered the annihilation of Dacke's entire family, but showed some leniency against those who had given themselves up. Thus, the unity of the realm was restored.
As a result of the war, the king was henceforth more careful when dealing with his subjects. The reliance on foreign mercenaries in the army was reduced in favour of soldiers of Swedish extraction (many of which were recruited in Småland), and this laid the foundation for Sweden's military successes in later wars.
==Legacy== Today, Nils Dacke is perceived as a Småland freedom hero. His name is often linked to an independent streak in Småland. Statues in memory of him have been erected, including one in [[Virserum]], where the final battle allegedly took place during 1543. The [[:sv:Nils Dacke-partiet|Nils Dacke party]] (''Nils Dacke-partiet'') is a local political party in the county of [[Gnosjö]]. ''[[:sv:M/S Nils Dacke|M/S Nils Dacke]]'' is a vessel, owned by [[:sv:TT-Line|TT-Line]] serving the [[Trelleborg]]-[[Świnoujście]] route. In 1961, a made-for-television film entitled ''Dacke'' was released by Swedish director and screenwriter [[:sv:Bengt Lagerkvist|Bengt Lagerkvist]].
==See also== *[[Dacke War]] *[[Fabian Månsson]] ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} ==Other sources== *[[Vilhelm Moberg|Moberg, Vilhelm]] ''History of The Swedish People'' (Heinemann. 1973) {{ISBN|978-0-434-47301-4}} * Larsson, Lars-Olof ''Dackeland'' (Norstedt. 1979) {{ISBN|978-91-1-793312-8}} ==External links== *[http://www.ttline.com/sv/Skandinavien/Om-TT-Line/Vara-fartyg/Robin-Hood--Nils-Dacke/ M/S Nils Dacke]
{{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Dacke, Nils}} [[Category:1543 deaths]] [[Category:Rebels]] [[Category:Deaths by firearm in Sweden]] [[Category:Swedish Christians]] [[Category:Swedish rebels]] [[Category:16th-century Swedish people]] [[Category:Year of birth unknown]] [[Category:Peasant revolts]]

{{short description|Arthurian Legend element}}
The '''nine sorceresses''' or '''nine sisters''' are a recurring element in [[Arthurian legend]] in variants of the popular [[Nine maidens (mythology)|nine maidens]] theme from world mythologies. Their most important appearances are in [[Geoffrey of Monmouth]]'s introduction of [[Avalon]] and the character that would later become [[Morgan le Fay]], and as the central motif of [[Peredur]]'s story in the ''[[Peredur son of Efrawg]]'' part of the ''[[Mabinogion]]''.
== The maidens of Annwfn and the witches of Ystawingun == [[File:Cauldron_of_Inspiration.jpg|thumb|The nine maidens of Annwn in ''The Cauldron of Inspirations'', an illustration by [[Ernest Wallcousins]] (1912)|alt=]]
In ''[[Preiddeu Annwfn]]'', the nine virgin priestesses of the otherworldy island of Annwfn ([[Annwn]], the Welsh version of the [[Celtic Otherworld]]) guard a magic cauldron, and their magic abilities seem to include fire-breathing.<ref name="gca">{{Cite book|url=http://www.arthuriana.co.uk/concepts/Green_Concepts_of_Arthur_2007.pdf|title=Concepts of Arthur|last=Green|first=Thomas|publisher=Tempus Publishing|year=2007|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref> A raid by [[King Arthur|Arthur]] and his warband either steals<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=E0bdCQAAQBAJ&pg=PT36|title=King Arthur's Battle for Britain|first=Eric|last=Walmsley|date=2013|publisher=Troubador Publishing Ltd|via=Google Books|page=36}}</ref> or destroys the cauldron,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gCvor7LpqVIC&pg=PA114|title=Origins of Arthurian Romances: Early Sources for the Legends of Tristan, the Grail and the Abduction of the Queen|first=Flint F.|last=Johnson|date=2012|publisher=McFarland|via=Google Books}}</ref> but what happens to the maidens of Annwfn is not mentioned. The motif of nine supernatural women appears also in some other tales of the Celtic Otherworld,<ref name="ga">{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nl8oDwAAQBAJ&pg=PT40|title=Grail Alchemy: Initiation in the Celtic Mystery Tradition|first=Mara|last=Freeman|date=2014|publisher=Simon and Schuster|via=Google Books|page=40}}</ref> possibly derived from sisterhoods of priestesses of the old [[Druid#The Gallizenae|Celtic Religion]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=GYWrAgAAQBAJ|title=The Arthurian Handbook, Second Edition: Second Edition|first1=Norris J.|last1=Lacy|first2=Geoffrey|last2=Ashe|first3=Debra N.|last3=Mancoff|date=2014|publisher=Routledge|via=Google Books}}</ref>
The nine witches of Ystawingun (Ystavingun) are mentioned in a single line of the 10-century poem ''Pa Gur yv y Porthaur'', where the feat of slaying them in this highland is listed among the greatest achievements of Cai ([[Sir Kay]] in later tradition). Ystawingun is unidentified but might be associated with [[Stanton Moor]] and its stone circle known as "Nine Ladies"<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dsUqAQAAMAAJ|title=Shadows in the Mist: The Life and Death of King Arthur|last=Hunt|first=August|date=2006|publisher=Hayloft|isbn=9781904524380|language=en}}</ref> or with [[Portskewett|Porthsgiwed]].<ref name="gca" /> According to [[John and Caitlin Matthews]], the women whose killing Cai is credited with in ''Pa Gur'' are in fact the same as the pagan priestesses from ''Preiddeu Annwfn''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RGEoDwAAQBAJ&pg=PT194|title=The Complete King Arthur: Many Faces, One Hero|last1=Matthews|first1=John|last2=Matthews|first2=Caitlín|date=2017|publisher=Simon and Schuster|page=194|via=Google Books}}</ref>
Scholars like [[Norris J. Lacy]] and [[John T. Koch]] make an additional (besides ''Preiddeu Annwfn'') connection also to the nine witch sisters and their mother in the 7th-century [[Breton lai]] ''Vita Prima Samsonis''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=34bZBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA1889|title=Medieval Arthurian Literature: A Guide to Recent Research|first=Norris J.|last=Lacy|date=2014|publisher=Routledge|via=Google Books|page=1889}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=f899xH_quaMC&pg=PA325|title=Celtic Culture: A historical encyclopedia. Vol. 1|first=John T.|last=Koch|publisher=ABC-CLIO|date=2006|via=Google Books|page=325}}</ref> Her description resembles that of the Irish goddess [[Mórrígan]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=mVz_AQAAQBAJ&pg=PA161|title=The Witch Figure: Folklore essays by a group of scholars in England honouring the 75th birthday of Katharine M. Briggs|last=Newall|first=Venetia|date=2004|publisher=Routledge|page=161|via=Google Books}}</ref> In this work, [[Saint Samson of Dol]] encounters just one of the sisters, a wild-looking wicked witch (''malefica'') calling herself '''Theomacha''' (Enemy of God), as she was flying through a forest on the island of Loire and attacking one of his young deacons. Samson calls for her to repent and convert, but she refuses and tells him she wishes to do nothing but evil as she did her whole life. After that Theomacha attempts to flee, but Samson commands her to stay in place, rendering her utterly immobile in the air, and offers her last final chance but she proves to be beyond salvation. Samson then proceeds to pray for such utterly irredeemable woman's destruction; as soon as he finishes his prayer, she drops down dead.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SVpQ2GTKkE4C|title=Medievalia Et Humanistica: Studies in Medieval & Renaissance Culture|first=Paul Maurice|last=Clogan|date=2003|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|via=Google Books}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BbQ4DwAAQBAJ&pg=PA27|title=St Samson of Dol and the Earliest History of Brittany, Cornwall and Wales|first=Lynette|last=Olson|date=2017|publisher=Boydell & Brewer|via=Google Books|page=27}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=V70nCDxlFgEC&pg=PA152|title=The British Sources of the Abduction and Grail Romances|first=Flint|last=Johnson|date=2002|publisher=University Press of America|via=Google Books|page=152}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=f899xH_quaMC&pg=PA1558|title=Celtic Culture: A historical encyclopedia. Vol. 1|first=John T.|last=Koch|publisher=ABC-CLIO|via=Google Books|page=1558}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=http://repository.uwtsd.ac.uk/596/1/Krajewski%2C%20E.%20Archetypal%20narratives.pdf|title=ARCHETYPAL NARRATIVES: TOWARD A THEOLOGICAL APPRECIATION OF EARLY CELTIC HAGIOGRAPHY|last=Krajewski|first=Elizabeth M. G.|publisher=University of Wales Trinity Saint David|year=2015|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BbQ4DwAAQBAJ&pg=PA28|title=St Samson of Dol and the Earliest History of Brittany, Cornwall and Wales|first=Lynette|last=Olson|date=2017|publisher=Boydell & Brewer|via=Google Books|page=28}}</ref>
==The sisters of Avalon== [[File:King Arthur in Avalon.png|thumb|250px|''King Arthur in Avalon'', an illustration by [[Dante Gabriel Rossetti]] (1857)|alt=|left]]{{Further information|Morgan le Fay}}
[[Geoffrey of Monmouth]]'s 12-century ''[[Vita Merlini]]'' introduces the magical island of [[Avalon]], the paradisal "Isle of Apples", as ruled by the nine entirely benevolent enchantress-sisters, known as great healers and capable of shape-shifting and other magic: '''Morgen''', '''Moronoe''', '''Mazoe''', '''Gliten''', '''Glitonea''', '''Gliton''', '''Tyronoe''', and either '''Thiten''' and '''Thiton''' or two sisters both named '''Thitis''' of whom one of them distinguished as "best known for her [[cither]]".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TUpue_j4D5AC&pg=PA32|title=King Arthur's French Odyssey: Avallon in Burgundy|first=Marilyn|last=Floyde|date=2009|publisher=Pegasus Elliot Mackenzie Pu|via=Google Books|page=32}}</ref> The sisters receive the dying Arthur from [[Taliesin]], delivered to them in a hope they can revive him.<ref name=ga/> Their beautiful, wise and powerful queen, Morgen, would later evolve into [[Morgan le Fay]], Arthur's own sister in later Arthurian tradition, who herself takes the dying Arthur to Avalon.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=w2Ayg7hw-cgC&pg=PA39|title=Merlin: Knowledge and Power Through the Ages|first=Stephen Thomas|last=Knight|date=2009|publisher=Cornell University Press|via=Google Books|page=39}}</ref> The other eight sisters appear only in this text and never return in any known works by other medieval authors.
It is very possible that the author was inspired, besides the stories such as ''Preiddeu Annwfn'',<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UXoqDwAAQBAJ&pg=PA1516|title=The Encyclopedia of Medieval Literature in Britain|first1=Sian|last1=Echard|first2=Robert|last2=Rouse|date=2017|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|via=Google Books|page=1516}}</ref> by an ancient Roman description of the island [[Île de Sein|Sein]] off the coast of [[Brittany]],<ref name="dka" /> depicted by the 1st century geographer [[Pomponius Mela]] as being ruled by nine virgin priestesses wielding incredible magic powers.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YlkoDwAAQBAJ&pg=SA13-PA93|title=Mysteries of the Ancient Past: A Graham Hancock Reader|first=Glenn|last=Kreisberg|date=2012|publisher=Simon and Schuster|via=Google Books}}</ref> Other possible connections involve the [[Greek mythology]] figures of [[Circe]], [[Medea]], and the nine [[muses]] (most of the sisters have Greek-style names).<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://lra.le.ac.uk/bitstream/2381/10954/1/2012enstonezphd.pdf|title='Wichecraft & Vilaine': Morgan le Fay in Medieval Arthurian Literature|last=Enstone|first=Zoë Eve|publisher=University of Leicester|year=2011|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref> Geoffrey's Avalon is also connected to Annwn; Morgen is even actually called "goddess of Annwn" in an early manuscript.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nl8oDwAAQBAJ&pg=PT42|title=Grail Alchemy: Initiation in the Celtic Mystery Tradition|first=Mara|last=Freeman|date=2014|publisher=Simon and Schuster|via=Google Books}}</ref>
{{Clear}}
==The sorceresses of Caer Lloyw== The nine make their final<ref name=dka>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_j6Py7x_ctIC&pg=PA49|title=The Druids and King Arthur: A New View of Early Britain|first=Robin|last=Melrose|date=2011|publisher=McFarland|via=Google Books|page=49}}</ref> written appearance in the ''[[Peredur son of Efrawg]]'' part of the ''[[Mabinogion]]'', wherein [[Peredur]] (a variant of [[Percival]]) faces many opponents throughout the course of the story. However, his real enemies are eventually revealed as the ''Gwiddonod Caerloyw'' - the malignant ''Nine Witches of Caer Lloyw'' (or Caerloyw, literally the Castle of Glow in English,<ref name=jr/> or the "Shining Fortress",<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=a1h4O_7A1iYC&pg=PA21|title=The Development of Arthurian Romance|first=Roger Sherman|last=Loomis|date=2000|publisher=Courier Corporation|via=Google Books|page=21}}</ref> later identified as [[Gloucester]]), also known as the ''Nine Sorceresses of Gloucester''. Here they are fearsome mistresses of warfare and magic who terrorize Britain and whose evil deeds are responsible for ravaging his uncle's kingdom. It is a variant of an Arthurian [[Holy Grail|Grail]] tale in which, instead of questing for the Grail, the hero takes part in ridding the land of the plague (''gormes''<ref name=gg>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2snYAAAAMAAJ|title=Peredur: A study of Welsh tradition in the Grail legends|first=Glenys|last=Goetinck|date=1975|publisher=University of Wales Press [for] the Language and Literature Committee of the Board of Celtic Studies|via=Google Books}}</ref>) of evil witches that must be destroyed.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=V70nCDxlFgEC&pg=PA202|title=The British Sources of the Abduction and Grail Romances|first=Flint|last=Johnson|date=2002|publisher=University Press of America|via=Google Books|page=202}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lEvaAAAAMAAJ|title=Mythologie française|date=8 December 1987|publisher=Société de mythologie française|via=Google Books|language=French}}</ref> The witches, a group of black-clad "maiden-hags",<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_qbPrsL3KeoC&pg=PA155|title=Welsh Mythology: A Neostructuralist Analysis|first=Jonathan|last=Miles-Watson|date=2009|publisher=Cambria Press|via=Google Books|page=155}}</ref> actually enter the story as Peredur's opponents-turned-benefactors, even giving him the same powers as they have when he spends time in their home,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_DIQ40S8TG4C&pg=PA170|title=The Grail: The Celtic Origins of the Sacred Icon|first=Jean|last=Markale|date=1999|publisher=Inner Traditions / Bear & Co|via=Google Books|language=Italian|page=170}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=82r8UFkloJYC&pg=PA81|title=L'iniziazione cavalleresca nella leggenda di Re Artù|first=Dominique|last=Viseux|date=2004|publisher=Edizioni Mediterranee|via=Google Books}}</ref> but the central theme is his eventual unenthusiastic revenge on them for having previously harmed his relatives.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vVquBwAAQBAJ&pg=PT17|title=The Holy Grail: History and Legend|first=Juliette|last=Wood|date=2012|publisher=University of Wales Press|via=Google Books|page=17}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BpuOdmHOi3AC&pg=PA22|title=A History of Arthurian Scholarship|first=Norris J.|last=Lacy|date=2006|publisher=Boydell & Brewer Ltd|via=Google Books|page=22}}</ref> Peredur himself vanquishes only the chief witch, and only forced to do so after giving them three chances to yield,<ref name="auto">{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ITXXAAAAMAAJ|title=The Holy Grail: Its Origins, Secrets & Meaning Revealed|first=Malcolm|last=Godwin|date=1994|publisher=Viking|via=Google Books}}</ref> but this act breaks the magic of their spells<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=U6kJAQAAIAAJ|title=La Bretagne d'hier et de demain|first=Yann|last=Brékilien|date=1978|publisher=J. P. Delarge|via=Google Books|language=French}}</ref> and Arthur and his men slaughter the rest without mercy and with such as swiftness that not a single one escapes alive.
Relatively early on during his adventures, Peredur comes upon a mountain castle, the lady of which tells him how the surrounding lands have been conquered and laid to waste by the terrifying nine sorceresses, with powers too great for anyone to stop them,<ref name=kc>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-qIzhamrT2kC|title=King of the Celts: Arthurian Legends and Celtic Tradition|first=Jean|last=Markale|date=1993|publisher=Inner Traditions / Bear & Co|via=Google Books}}</ref> and that one is coming to take the castle the very next morning. But Peredur offers to help, and at dawn he fiercely attacks and subdues the arriving enchantress with a blow that shatters her helmet. He is just about to slay her but stops when she begs forgiveness; after obtaining permission from the lady of the castle, he agrees to spare her life if she promises to return to her land and that she and her sisters would never trouble the dominion of his hostess (Peredur regularly gives quarter to his defeated enemies through the course of the tale, including Kai and various other knights). He then sets off with the now befriended sorceress back to her palace at Caer Lloyw in the journey that itself is not described. Peredur stays at the Witches' Court (''Llys Gwiddonod'') for three weeks, being tutored by them until he finishes his training, and then he is sent off by their lady principal on his way with the horse and weapons of his choice.<ref name=tg>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ymIoDwAAQBAJ&pg=PT32|title=The Grail: The Celtic Origins of the Sacred Icon|first=Jean|last=Markale|date=1999|publisher=Simon and Schuster|via=Google Books|page=32}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4UVc6up1HJUC|title=Women of the Celts|first=Jean|last=Markale|date=1986|publisher=Inner Traditions / Bear & Co|via=Google Books}}</ref><ref name=tgl>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=w15tJYbQgBwC&pg=PA201|title=The Grail Legend|first1=Emma|last1=Jung|first2=Marie-Luise von|last2=Franz|date=1998|publisher=Princeton University Press|via=Google Books|page=201}}</ref>
During the grand finale at the original{{#tag:ref|The entire tale of Peredur ends either with the massacre of the witches or with Peredur's marriage to the Empress of [[Constantinople]] (a later addition), depending on the manuscript.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=V70nCDxlFgEC&pg=PA142|title=The British Sources of the Abduction and Grail Romances|first=Flint|last=Johnson|date=2002|publisher=University Press of America|via=Google Books|page=142}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DdjcvMbKuO0C&pg=PA181|title=She Is Everywhere!: An Anthology of Writings in Womanist/Feminist Spirituality|first1=Mary|last1=Saracino|first2=Mary Beth|last2=Moser|date=2012|publisher=iUniverse|via=Google Books|page=181}}</ref>|group="note"}} end of the tale, however, Peredur learns that a mysterious severed head (replacing the Grail in this story<ref name=tm>{{cite web|url=http://www.timelessmyths.com/arthurian/grail.html|title=Grail Legends|first=Jimmy|last=Joe|website=www.timelessmyths.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Rab3AgAAQBAJ|title=Eternal Chalice: The Enduring Legend of the Holy Grail|first=Juliette|last=Wood|date=2008|publisher=I.B.Tauris|via=Google Books}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pOWVGoO4kv8C&pg=PA221|title=Ring und Gral: Texte, Kommentare und Interpretationen zu Richard Wagners "Der Ring des Nibelungen", "Tristan und Isolde", "Die Meistersinger von Nürnberg" und "Parsifal" ; [Beiträge für die Bayreuther Festspiele 1988-2001]|first1=Ulrich|last1=Müller|first2=Oswald|last2=Panagl|date=2002|publisher=Königshausen & Neumann|via=Google Books|language=German|page=221}}</ref>), which he had witnessed before meeting the sorceresses, belonged to one his cousins. His foster-sister accuses the witches for the murder of his cousin and for having cursed and lamed of his uncle (an unnamed king of the realm, here a [[Fisher King]] figure), and tells Peredur that he is predestined to be their avenger. Peredur and his elder companion Gwalchmei ([[Gawain]]) decide to summon Arthur's warband to join them in this labour, and he leads them to Caer Lloyw to deal with the sorceresses.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3xEsCWEYFfkC&pg=PA48|title=Sources of the Grail: An Anthology|first=John|last=Matthews|date=1996|publisher=SteinerBooks|via=Google Books|page=48}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IW8LAQAAMAAJ|title=Quondam Et Futurus|date=1991|publisher=English Department, Memphis State University|via=Google Books}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tfNK-53rNaUC&pg=PA80|title=Parzival: An Introduction|first=Eileen|last=Hutchins|date=2012|publisher=Temple Lodge Publishing|via=Google Books|page=80}}</ref> During the ensuing showdown, the witches attack and Peredur watches the seemingly invincible leader of the enchantresses defeat Arthur's warriors one by one, as Peredur keeps pleading for her to desist and stop the fighting and give up but she does not listen; only after she kills the third one, Peredur finally enters the strife himself and swiftly strikes her down with a single powerful blow. With her dying breath, she cries out to the other witches they are doomed as Peredur was prophesied as the slayer of them all, and orders the other witches to getaway; however Arthur and the others rush and chase after the fleeing women until every last one is overtaken and put to the sword.<ref name="auto"/><ref name=tm/><ref name=yc>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QiczdZHaX6QC|title=Y Cymmrodor: The Magazine of the Honourable Society of Cymmrodorion|first1=Thomas|last1=Powel|first2=Sir Isambard|last2=Owen|first3=Egerton Grenville Bagot|last3=Phillimore|date=1904|publisher=The Society.|via=Google Books}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.timelessmyths.com/arthurian/quest1.html|title=Grail Legends (Perceval's Tradition)|first=Jimmy|last=Joe|website=www.timelessmyths.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3XgqDwAAQBAJ&pg=PA409|title=Handbook of Arthurian Romance: King Arthur's Court in Medieval European Literature|first1=Leah|last1=Tether|first2=Johnny|last2=McFadyen|date=2017|publisher=Walter de Gruyter|via=Google Books|page=409}}</ref>
The narrative does not actually say how many witches are gathered for the final battle at Caer Loyw when they are wiped out, and there might be more than the nine from the first encounter between them and Perodur; according to [[John Rhys]] it is suggested "they must have mustered in a great force," possibly along with (unmentioned) "numerous allies of the other sex."<ref name=jr/> In any case, Peredur's duty of vengeance was fulfilled and he is celebrated as hero for his role in freeing the kingdom of the great scourge of witchcraft - and, with the sorceresses now annihilated, Peredur himself becomes the last keeper of their magic secrets.<ref name=tg/> However, what happened to his uncle after the victory is left untold.<ref name=tgl/><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://issuu.com/themjlc/docs/mjlc_spring2013_final_web__2_/32|title=The Madison Journal of Literary Criticism - Volume 3|work=Issuu|access-date=2018-05-15|language=en}}</ref> [[Urban T. Holmes Jr.]] assumed that with the witches' death the king was freed from their enchantments,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=t5xcAAAAMAAJ|title=Chrétien de Troyes|first=Urban Tigner|last=Holmes|date=1970|publisher=Twayne Publishers|via=Google Books}}</ref> conversely [[Arthur Edward Waite]] assumed that the king was not healed and it was all in vain.<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://www.hourofthetime.com/1-LF/October2012/Hour_Of_The_Time_10312012-The_Hidden_Church_Of_The_Holy_Graal-1909.pdf|title=The Hidden Church of the Holy Graal|last=Waite|first=Arthur Edward|publisher=|year=1909|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref>
As in the cases of the above stories of Samson and Cai, this romance may be an echo of an otherwise unrecorded extermination of local Celtic pagan cults by Christians during the 5th and 6th centuries, as it is considered by Flint F. Johnson;<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=V70nCDxlFgEC&pg=PA208|title=The British Sources of the Abduction and Grail Romances|first=Flint|last=Johnson|date=2002|publisher=University Press of America|via=Google Books|page=208}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=K0Cmn4ps-X4C&pg=PA121|title=Origins of Arthurian Romances: Early Sources for the Legends of Tristan, the Grail and the Abduction of the Queen|first=Flint F.|last=Johnson|date=2012|publisher=McFarland|via=Google Books|page=454}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LDLwDQAAQBAJ&pg=PT213|title=The British Heroic Age: A History, 367–664|first=Flint F.|last=Johnson|date=2017|publisher=McFarland|via=Google Books|page=213}}</ref> Dhira B. Mahoney speculated the witches may "represent the supporters of an older order trying to regain control of the system."<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=avjgAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA136|title=The Grail: A Casebook|last=Mahoney|first=Dhira B.|date=2014-06-23|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781317947257|language=en}}</ref> Elsewhere in the ''Mabinogion'', the tale of ''[[Culhwch and Olwen]]'' likewise features the motif of Arthur's attack on Caer Loyw, but in this case the defenders of the castle are male.<ref name="jr">{{Cite book|url=https://archive.org/details/cu31924087972927|title=Studies in the Arthurian legend|last=Rhys|first=John|date=1891|publisher=Oxford, Clarendon Press|others=Cornell University Library}}</ref> Arthur also hunts down Orddu (the Black Witch) and kills her by slicing her in half after she repeatedly beats his men who first struggle to defeat her, reminiscent of how Peredur dispatched of the witch queen of Caer Lloyw.<ref name=gca/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3XgqDwAAQBAJ&pg=PA408|title=Handbook of Arthurian Romance: King Arthur's Court in Medieval European Literature|first1=Leah|last1=Tether|first2=Johnny|last2=McFadyen|date=2017|publisher=Walter de Gruyter|via=Google Books|page=408}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CJJ4AAAAIAAJ|title=Studies in Welsh Arthurian romance: Peredur and Trystan|first1=James E.|last1=Doan|date=1990|publisher=Irish Studies Program, Northeastern University|via=Google Books}}</ref> Furthermore, parts of the story parallel how the Irish mythological hero [[Cú Chulainn]] is thought combat by the warrior woman [[Scáthach]] after he overcomes and threatens her; Cú Chulainn also defeats Scáthach's rival [[Aífe]], sparing her life but raping her, and many years later comes to fight and kill their son of this union.<ref name="jr" /><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=TYZiAAAAMAAJ|title=The Celtic West and Europe: Studies in Celtic Literature and the Early Irish Church|last=Edel|first=Doris|date=2001|publisher=Four Courts Press|isbn=9781851822690|language=en}}</ref> Norma Lorre Goodrich connects the motif with "magical warrior rites in Scotland" and links the witches' leader to the figure of Queen Morgan le Fay, a sorcerous half-sister of Arthur.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9jUDAAAAIAAJ|title=The Holy Grail|last=Goodrich|first=Norma Lorre|date=1992|publisher=HarperCollins Publishers|language=en}}</ref> According to [[Roger Sherman Loomis]], it is possible that the author either indeed had Morgan in mind for the ''gwiddon'' or that both he and Goeffrey were taking from the same sources in earlier tradition.<ref name="gg" />

{{Use Indian English|date=June 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2015}} {{Infobox Indian politician | image = | name = Nirmal Chandra Chatterjee | caption = | birth_date = | birth_place = | residence = Boinchee, [[Hooghly District]], [[Bengal Presidency]] ,[[British India]] | death_date = | death_place = | office = [[Member of Parliament]], [[Lok Sabha]] | constituency1 = [[Hooghly (Lok Sabha constituency)|Hooghly]], [[West Bengal]] | salary1 = | term_start1 = 1952 | term_end1 = 1957 | predecessor1 = | successor1 = Provat Kar | constituency2 = [[Burdwan (Lok Sabha constituency)|Burdwan ]], [[West Bengal]] | salary2 = | term_start2 = 1963 | term_end2 = 1971 | predecessor2 = Guru Gobinda Basu | successor2 = [[Somnath Chatterjee]] | party =[[ Communist party of India, Hindu Mahasabha]] | religion = | spouse = Binapani Devi | children = 2 Sons and 3 daughters including [[Somnath Chatterjee]] | website = | footnotes = | date = | year = | source =http://164.100.47.194/loksabha/writereaddata/biodata_1_12/650.htm }} '''Nirmal Chandra Chatterjee''' (1895–1971) was an Indian jurist who served as president of the [[Akhil Bharatiya Hindu Mahasabha|All-India Hindu Mahasabha]].<ref name=NCC>[http://164.100.47.132/LssNew/biodata_1_12/650.htm Chatterjee, Nirmal Chandra]</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=https://swarajyamag.com/politics/but-for-nehru-somnath-chatterjee-would-have-been-a-dharmic | title=From A Hindu To A Communist: The Political Journey Of Somnath Chatterjee | publisher=Swarajyamag | work=Jaideep Mazumdar | date=13 August 2018 | accessdate=14 August 2018}}</ref>
==Early life and education== He was born on 19 October 1895 in Boinchee, in the [[Hooghly district]] to Bholanath Chatterjee. He was educated at the [[South Suburban School (Main)|South Suburban School]], the Mitra Institution, St. Mary's School, all in Calcutta, before graduating from the [[Scottish Church College]]. Subsequently, he studied law at the [[Hazra Law College]] of the [[University of Calcutta]], before proceeding on to the [[Middle Temple]], London, and subsequently finishing his academic pursuit at the [[University College, London]].<ref name=NCC/>
==Career==
He started out as a senior advocate in the [[Supreme Court of India]]. He went on to be a judge at the [[Calcutta High Court]]. Later he became the vice president of the Supreme Court Bar Association, and treasurer of the [[Bar Association of India]]. He had also served as a president of the [[All India Civil Liberties Council]], and as vice president of the [[International Commission of Jurists]] - Indian Branch.<ref name=NCC/>
He became the President of All India Hindu Mahasabha and presided over its<ref>{{cite book|last1=Chatterjee|first1=Somnath|title=Keeping the faith|publisher=Harper Collins|pages=13}}</ref> Gwalior session in 1947. But after partition and assassination of Mahatma Gandhi, he somewhat disenchent with party politics. Towards the end of 1947 and early 1948, he felt ill quite frequently and months could not attend his professional work. Doctors advised him that because of the serious attack of epidemic dropsy, he would not be able to lead an active life anymore. At that time, he got an offer for appointment as a Judge of Calcutta High court and he agreed to accept.
He was also a member of the Special Committee on Tibet of the International Commission of Jurists, and a chairman of the Subordinate Legislation Committee of Parliament. He represented India at the Commonwealth Law Conference held in London in 1955. He was a deputy leader of the Indian Lawyers Delegation to the [[USSR]] in 1959, and represented India at the International Bar Conference at [[Salzburg]] in [[Austria]] in 1960 and Commonwealth Law Conference held at Sydney in 1966. He was counsel for India at the [[Kutch]] International Tribunal in [[Geneva]].<ref name=NCC/>
He was a member of the [[1st Lok Sabha]] (1952-1957) from [[Hooghly (Lok Sabha constituency)|Hooghly]] as an [[Akhil Bharatiya Hindu Mahasabha]] candidate, [[3rd Lok Sabha]] after he won a bye-poll in 1963 as an independent from [[Burdwan (Lok Sabha constituency)|Burdwan]] with CPI support and [[4th Lok Sabha]] (1967-1971) when he won again from [[Burdwan (Lok Sabha constituency)|Burdwan]] as an independent. He died in 1971. The [[Burdwan (Lok Sabha constituency)|Burdwan]] seat was won by his son [[Somnath Chatterjee]] in 1971 general election, as a [[Communist Party of India (Marxist)]] candidate.
==Family== He married Binapani Devi on 30 May 1915, and later became the father of Debnath Chatterjee, his eldest son and other was the Marxist leader, Parliamentarian [[Somnath Chatterjee]], a fiercely anti-Hindutva communist leader from Bengal who served as the 14th [[Speaker of the Lok Sabha]] from 2004 to 2009.
==Books written by him== *''Company Law'' *''Awakening of India'' *''Problems of Jammu and Kashmir'' *''Comparative Jurisprudence'' *''Indian Constitutional Law'' *''Fundamental Rights and Judicial Review'' *''Emergency and Law''<ref name=NCC/>
==Other works== *Monographs and articles on historical, legal and constitutional topics *Paper on 'Nationality' at International legal Conference in Delhi in January, 1954 *Studies in history, political science, economics, Indology, comparative politics and international law and travelling *Social activities by helping depressed classes and Harijans, championing civil liberties and rule of law.<ref name=NCC/>
==Sports and hobbies== *Gardening *President, Bhawanipur Club *Member, Chelmsford Club Delhi and [[Calcutta Club]].<ref name=NCC/>

{{Infobox person | name = Oleksandr Ivanovych Muzychko | image = Oleksandr Muzychko.jpg | alt = | caption = Oleksandr Muzychko during the [[First Chechen War]] | birth_name = <!--only use if different from name--> | birth_date = {{Birth date|1962|09|19|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Kizel]], [[Perm Oblast]], [[Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic|Russian SFSR]], [[Soviet Union]] | death_date = {{Death date and age|2014|03|24|1962|07|19|df=y}} | death_place = Café "Try Karasi" near [[Rivne]], [[Rivne Oblast]], [[Ukraine]] | nationality = Ukrainian and Belarusian | other_names = Sashko Bilyi | occupation = Political activist | known_for = Coordinator of [[Right Sector]] in Western Ukraine }}
'''Oleksandr Ivanovych Muzychko''' ([[Ukrainian language|Ukrainian]]: Олександр Іванович Музичко, 19 September 1962 – 24 March 2014<ref name=presUkr>{{cite news|title=Вбито Сашка Білого (Музичко)|url=http://uapress.info/uk/news/show/19566|newspaper=Преса України|date=25 March 2014}}</ref><ref name=KP>{{cite news|title=Сашко Билый убит?|url=http://www.kp.ru/daily/26210/3095196/|newspaper=[[Komsomolskaya Pravda]]|date=25 March 2014}}</ref>), nicknamed '''Sashko Bilyi''' (Сашко Білий), was a Ukrainian political activist, a member of [[UNA-UNSO]] and coordinator of [[Right Sector]] in Western Ukraine.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://zik.ua/ua/news/2014/02/12/koordynatorom_pravogo_sektora_u_zahidniy_ukraini_stav_oleksandr_muzychko_460093|title=Координатор "Правого сектору" у Західній Україні – Олександр Музичко|publisher=zik.ua|accessdate=2014-03-08}}</ref> Russian prosecutors accused him of killing "at least 20" captive Russian soldiers during the [[First Chechen War]]. The inquiry by the Russian Investigative Committee began in March 2014, years after the alleged killings.<ref>{{citation |url=http://au.news.yahoo.com/world/a/22169475/ukrainian-police-kill-far-right-leader-oleksandr-muzytchko/ |title=Ukrainian police kill far-right leader Oleksandr Muzytchko |agency=AFP |date=2014-03-26 |publisher=Yahoo News |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fau.news.yahoo.com%2Fworld%2Fa%2F22169475%2Fukrainian-police-kill-far-right-leader-oleksandr-muzytchko%2F&date=2014-03-25 |archivedate=2014-03-25 |quote=Russia had issued an arrest warrant for Muzytchko on suspicion that he fought alongside Islamists in the war in Chechnya where he was responsible for the deaths of 20 Russian soldiers, according to Russian news agencies. |deadurl=no }}</ref><ref> {{citation |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/morning-mix/wp/2014/03/25/notorious-leader-of-ukraines-protests-dragged-out-of-car-shot-dead/?tid=pm_national_pop |title=Notorious leader of Ukraine's protests shot dead. Circumstances are in dispute. |last=McCoy |first=Terrence |date=2014-03-25 |publisher=Washington Post |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.washingtonpost.com%2Fnews%2Fmorning-mix%2Fwp%2F2014%2F03%2F25%2Fnotorious-leader-of-ukraines-protests-dragged-out-of-car-shot-dead%2F%3Ftid%3Dpm_national_pop&date=2014-03-26 |archivedate=2014-03-26 |quote=Earlier this month, nearly two decades after the Chechen conflict subsided, the Russian Investigative Committee opened a criminal inquiry against Muzychko. Spokesman Vladimir Markin accused Muzychko of 'killing at least 20 [Russian] soldiers held in captivity,' and put him on the 'international most wanted list.' |deadurl=no }} </ref>
Muzychko had vowed to fight "[[communist]]s, [[Jews]] and [[Russians]] for as long as blood flows in my veins".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://globalnews.ca/news/1194100/blind-eye-turned-to-influence-of-far-right-in-ukrainian-crisis-critics/|title=Blind eye turned to influence of far-right in Ukrainian crisis: critics|publisher=[[Global News]]|date=March 7, 2014}}</ref>
==Biography== Muzychko was born near the [[Ural Mountains]] to a Ukrainian father and a [[Belarusians|Belarusian]] mother, both deported members of the [[Ukrainian Insurgent Army]].<ref>[http://www.svaboda.org/content/article/25309215.html Маці Сашка Белага — беларуска, удзельніца УПА (The Mother of Sashko Bily is Belarusian, member of the UPA)] - Report by the Belarusian service of [[Radio Free Europe]]. 24 March 2015</ref>
During the First Chechen War he led the UNA-UNSO "Viking" group. In 1995 Muzychko was convicted of causing grievous bodily harm to an individual. In 1997 he was accused of attempting to kill a member of UNA-UNSO in Kiev.<ref>[http://espreso.tv/new/2014/03/25/%E2%80%8Bp%E2%80%99yat_faktiv_z_zhyttya_sashka_biloho Five facts from the life of Sasha Bilyi]. Espreso. March 25, 2014</ref> In 2003 Muzychko was sentenced to 3.5 years in prison for racketeering and kidnapping. In 2009 he was accused in a hostile [[corporate raid]]. In 2012 he ran for the [[Verkhovna Rada|Ukrainian parliament]] in the 153rd electoral district ([[Rivne]]) coming sixth. {{ external media | float = right | video1 = [//www.youtube.com/watch?v=TmzlrtSEu90 Muzychko and the Rivne prosecutor] }}
On 27 February 2014, Muzychko attacked the Prosecutor of the Rivne Oblast in his office and threatened to "slay as a dog" the Minister of Internal Affairs [[Arsen Avakov (politician)|Arsen Avakov]].<ref>[http://uapress.info/uk/news/show/17541 Sashko Bilyi: I will destroy Avakov and hang him like a dog (Video)]. uapress. March 1, 2014</ref> On 28 February 2014, criminal proceedings were opened against him.<ref>[http://uapress.info/uk/news/show/17528 Sashko Bilyi "activist and revolutionary," which beats the prosecutor - an outlaw]. uapress. February 28, 2014</ref><ref>[http://uapress.info/uk/news/show/17460 Activist of the Right Sector Oleksandr Muzychko will be dealt by prosecutors]. uapress. February 28, 2014</ref>
On 7 March 2014, ITAR-TASS reported that he was wanted by Russian authorities for war atrocities.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://en.itar-tass.com/russia/722557|title=Suspected Ukrainian gunman put on international wanted list|publisher=itar-tass.com|accessdate=2014-03-08}}</ref> On 11 March 2014, Russian [[State Duma]] opposition leader [[Valery Rashkin]] urged Russian special services to "follow [[Mossad]] examples" and assassinate Right Sector leaders [[Dmytro Yarosh]] and Muzychko.<ref>{{cite news|title=Российский депутат призвал спецслужбы "ликвидировать" Яроша и Белого|url=http://lenta.ru/news/2014/03/11/komm/|newspaper=[[Lenta.ru]]|date=11 March 2014}}</ref>
===Death=== On 24 March 2014 Oleksandr Muzychko was shot dead. There are conflicting stories about how this happened.<ref name=bbcPoliceRaid /> An official inquiry concluded he had shot himself in the heart three times at the end of a police chase.<ref name=bbc-20140402/>
According to Ukrainian MP Oles Doniy,<ref name=bbcPoliceRaid /> a group of unknown armed people arrived in three Volkswagen minivans and kidnapped Muzychko and five other people from a café near [[Rivne]]. They murdered Muzychko behind the café with two gunshots to the heart.<ref>{{cite web|title=ФОТОРЕПОРТАЖ З МІСЦЯ РОЗСТРІЛУ ОЛЕКСАНДРА МУЗИЧКА|url=http://charivne.info/news/Fotoreportazh-z-mistsya-rozstrilu-Oleksandra-Muzichka-}}</ref><ref name=KP/><ref>{{cite news|title=На Украине убит активист "Правого сектора" Сашко Билый|url=http://vladnews.ru/2014/03/25/78356/na-ukraine-ubili-aktivista-pravogo-sektora-sashko-bilyj.html|accessdate=25 March 2014|newspaper=Vladnews|date=25 March 2014}}</ref> In another telling of Doniy's account, a group of attackers forced Muzychko to halt his car, pulled him out of the vehicle, handcuffed him and shot him.<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.themoscowtimes.com/news/article/ultranationalist-leader-in-maidan-protests-is-shot-dead-in-ukraine-video/496788.html |title=Ultranationalist Leader in Maidan Protests Is Shot Dead in Ukraine (Video) |last=Dolgov |first=Anna |date=2014-03-25 |publisher=Moscow Times |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6OL2MVd48?url=http://www.themoscowtimes.com/news/article/ultranationalist-leader-in-maidan-protests-is-shot-dead-in-ukraine-video/496788.html |archivedate=2014-03-25 |quote=Ukrainian lawmaker Oleksandr Doniy said on his Facebook page that unknown assailants blocked off Muzychko's car, dragged him out of the vehicle, cuffed his hands behind his back, and shot him twice in the chest. |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref><ref>{{citation |url=http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/right-sector-coordinator-muzychko-killed-in-ukraines-rivne-340741.html |title=Right Sector coordinator Muzychko killed in Ukraine's Rivne |date=2014-03-25 |publisher=Kyiv Post |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.kyivpost.com%2Fcontent%2Fukraine%2Fright-sector-coordinator-muzychko-killed-in-ukraines-rivne-340741.html&date=2014-03-25 |archivedate=2014-03-25 |quote='Two vehicles cut up his car, after which he was dragged out of his car and forced into one of these vehicles. He was then thrown out of the vehicle handcuffed behind his back and with two gunshot wounds to his heart,' Doniy said. |deadurl=no }}</ref>
According to the interior ministry of Ukraine, Muzychko died in a shoot-out with police in a café in Rivne. According to the ministry, the police raided the café to arrest Muzychko, but he opened fire while he tried to flee. He was shot when the police returned fire. The police were able to capture him and three others, but by the time the paramedics had arrived at the scene, he had died.<ref name=bbcPoliceRaid>{{cite news|title=Ukraine far-right leader Muzychko dies 'in police raid'|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-26729273|accessdate=25 March 2014|newspaper=Ukraine far-right leader Muzychko dies 'in police raid'|date=25 March 2014}}</ref><ref>{{citation |url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/world/ukraine-nationalist-oleksandr-muzychko-killed-in-police-operation-1.2585124 |title=Ukraine nationalist Oleksandr Muzychko killed in police operation |agency=Associated Press |date=2014-03-25 |quote=The Interior Ministry said Tuesday that Muzychko was shot dead after opening fire on police. }}</ref>
On 25 March, police stated that Muzychko had shot himself.<ref name=kyivpost-suicide>{{citation |url=http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/police-kill-radical-right-sector-activist-340835.html |title=Radical Right Sector activist killed in police raid; investigators raise possibility of self-inflicted wounds |last=Rudenko |first=Olga |date=2014-03-25 |publisher=Kyiv Post |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.kyivpost.com%2Fcontent%2Fukraine%2Fpolice-kill-radical-right-sector-activist-340835.html&date=2014-03-25 |archivedate=2014-03-25 |quote= |deadurl=no }}</ref> This was confirmed by an inquiry by the interior ministry, who concluded he had shot himself in the heart as police tried to bring him to the ground after a chase. The inquiry also concluded he had fired previously, resulting in a scratch on his skin, and that the police had acted lawfully.<ref name=bbc-20140402>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-26849934 |title=Ukraine far-right leader Sashko Bily 'shot himself' |publisher=BBC |date=2 April 2014 |accessdate=12 April 2014}}</ref>
Reacting to the news about shooting Dmytro Yarosh leader of Right Sector, called for resignation of Interior Minister [[Arsen Avakov]] and the arrest of the police officers who came after Muzychko.<ref name=kyivpost-suicide/> Unknown member of the Right Sector promised to reprisal to the minister for his death.<ref>[http://dt.ua/UKRAINE/praviy-sektor-poobicyav-pomstitisya-avakovu-za-vbivstvo-sashka-bilogo-140358_.html «Правий сектор» пообіцяв помститися Авакову за вбивство Сашка Білого] // Зеркало недели. — 2014. — 25 марта.{{ref-uk}}</ref>
10 days before his death Alexander Muzychko accused ukrainian police ([[Ministry of Internal Affairs (Ukraine)|MIA]]) and general prosecutor offices in preparation of his assassination.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://tsn.ua/ukrayina/vbitiy-sashko-biliy-za-10-dniv-do-smerti-zaklikav-priyizditi-grohnuti-yogo-341689.html|title=Вбитий Сашко Білий за 10 днів до смерті закликав "приїздити грохнути його"|date=2014-03-25|work=ТСН.ua|access-date=2018-08-10|language=uk}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://pravyysektor.info/oficiyno/zvernennya/zayava-oleksandra-muzychka-sashka-bilogo|title=Заява Олександра Музичка (Сашка Білого)|date=2014-03-14|work=Офіційний сайт НВР "Правий сектор|access-date=2018-08-10|language=uk}}</ref> According to Volodymyr Yevdokymov ({{Lang-uk|Володимир Євдокимов}}), a former officer of the [[Security Service of Ukraine|SSU]], Muzychko was «neutralized» during special operation of the SSU.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ria.ru/incidents/20140325/1000966992.html|title=Источник: целью спецоперации против Белого была его нейтрализация|publisher=[[Life News]]|accessdate=2014-03-27}}</ref>
==Legacy== In [[Konotop]] a street was named after Oleksandr Muzychko.<ref>[http://www.pravda.com.ua/rus/news/2015/12/10/7092126/]</ref>

[[Image:Plotina - sestertius - RIC 0740.jpg|thumb|300px|right|Pompeia Plotina coin, celebrating the [[Fides (mythology)|Fides]] on the reverse.]]
'''Pompeia Plotina Claudia Phoebe Piso''' or '''Pompeia Plotina''' (d. 121/122) was a Roman Empress and wife of [[Roman Emperor]] [[Trajan]]. She was renowned for her interest in philosophy, and her virtue, dignity and simplicity. She was particularly devoted to the [[Epicureanism|Epicurean]] philosophical school in [[Athens]], [[Greece]].<ref name=school>Simon Hornblower and Anthony Spawforth-E.A. (edd.), ''[[Oxford Classical Dictionary]],'' [[Oxford University Press]], 2003, p. 1214.</ref> She is often viewed as having provided Romans with fairer taxation, improved education, assisted the poor, and created tolerance in Roman society.
== Life == Plotina was born and was raised in Tejada la Vieja ([[Escacena del Campo]]) in the province of [[Hispania]], possibly during the reign of Roman Emperor [[Nero]] (r. 54–68). However, she could have been born in the 70s CE. She was the daughter of Lucius Pompeius and Plotia, who had extensive political and familial connections. Trajan married her before his accession and, although a happy marriage, they had no known children.
Upon entering the imperial palace following Trajan's ascension, Plotina is said to have turned to those watching her and carefully announced, "I enter here the kind of woman I would like to be when I depart."<ref>[[Dio Cassius]], LXVIII, 5</ref> It was through acts like this she sought to dispel the bad taste of domestic strife that had characterized the reign of [[Domitian]] as well as the [[Julio-Claudian dynasty]], where she acted like a traditional Roman matron, and was associated with chaste goddesses like [[Vesta (mythology)|Vesta]], the guardian of Rome's sacred fire, and [[Minerva]], goddess of war and wisdom.<ref>Annalise Freisenbruch, ''Caesars’ Wives: Sex, Power, and Politics in the Roman Empire'' (London and New York: Free Press, 2010), pp. 159-161</ref> In 100, Trajan awarded her with title of ''[[Augusta (honorific)|Augusta]]'', but she did not accept the title until 105. Plotina did not appear also on the coinage until 112.<ref name=school/>
When the future emperor [[Hadrian]] and his sister lost their parents at 10 or 11 years old, Trajan and the Roman officer [[Publius Acilius Attianus]] became their guardians; Hadrian was a first cousin once removed to Trajan (Trajan's father and Hadrian's paternal grandmother were siblings). Plotina was the matchmaker between Hadrian and his future wife [[Vibia Sabina]].<ref>''[[Historia Augusta]]'', "Hadrian", 3; translated by Anthony Birley, ''Lives of the Later Caesars'' (Harmondsworth: Penguin, 1976), p. 59</ref>
When a letter Trajan was said to have composed on his deathbed appeared in Rome with Plotina's signature on it, in which he adopted Hadrian and naming him successor to the Empire, suspicions were raised. It was rumoured that Attianus and the Empress Plotina had been lovers, both were very fond of Hadrian their ward, both were present at Trajan’s deathbed at [[Selinunte|Selinus]] in [[Sicily|Cilicia]] in August 117, and that the two had helped secure Hadrian's succession by forging Trajan’s will.<ref name="school"/>
Annelise Freisenbruch dismisses this accusation. "Plotina, the silent spouse of the second century, thus joined Livia, Agrippina Minor, and Domitia in the gallery of Roman imperial women accused of covering up or conspiring in their husband's deaths," Freisenbruch acidly writes, noting there are many plausible explanations why Plotina's signature might legitimately be on this declaration: Trajan may have simply been too weak to sign the letter himself. Freisenbruch also notes these kinds of accusations have dogged the spouses of rulers through the centuries, providing two modern examples of these kinds of accusations: in 1919 Edith Wilson was charged with forging the signature of US president [[Woodrow Wilson]] after he was incapacitated by a stroke; and four years later, when president [[Warren Harding]] died from a heart attack, his wife was then accused in a best-selling book of having poisoned him.<ref>Freisenbruch, ''Caesars’ Wives'', pp. 162f</ref>
Along with Attianus and [[Salonina Matidia|Matidia]], the grieving widow Plotina accompanied Trajan’s body to [[Seleucia Pieria|Seleucia]] and his ashes to Rome.
It was while a widow that Plotina's best documented action took place. During the year 121, while the emperor Hadrian was inspecting the provinces, Plotina and he engaged in a series of letters discussing who should be the new head of the [[Epicurean]] school of philosophy in [[Athens]]. She petitioned for a change in the law, which would allow [[Popillius Theotimus]], the acting head of the school, to become the actual head; in response, Hadrian agreed with her argument, and the relevant letters were preserved in a series of inscriptions. Freisenbruch notes, "In stark contrast to her passive anonymity in the literary record, this inscription from Athens recasts Plotina as a highly educated woman, active on behalf of causes close to her heart and with the kind of access to the emperor once enjoyed by Livia."<ref>Freisenbruch, ''Caesars’ Wives'', pp. 163f</ref>
When Plotina died of illness, she was [[Imperial cult (Roman Empire)|deified]]. Hadrian built a temple in her honor at [[Nîmes]], in [[Provence]].

{{BLP unsourced|date=July 2018}}{{Infobox officeholder | name = Dr. Safiatou Thiam | honorific-suffix = | image = Dr Safiétou thiam 1.JPG | caption = Dr. Safiatou Thiam (centre) | office = Minister for Health and Disease Prevention | term_start = 13 September 2007 | term_end = April 2009 | predecessor = [[Abdou Fall]] | successor = [[Thérèse Coumba Diop]] | nationality = [[Senegal]]ese | smallimage = | office1 = | term_start1 = | term_end1 = | predecessor1 = | office2 = | term_start2 = | term_end2 = | constituency2 = | birth_date = | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | party = | religion = | occupation = Medical doctor | alma_mater = [[Université Cheikh Anta Diop]] (Dakar), [[Université Pierre et Marie Curie]] (Paris VI) | website = |}}
'''Safiatou Thiam''' is a Senegalese [[public health]] [[Physician|doctor]], a specialist in [[HIV]]/[[AIDS]] and former Minister of Health and Disease Prevention in the government of [[Cheikh Hadjibou Soumaré]].She later became Executive Secretary of CNLS National Council against AIDS
==Early life== She earned her [[doctorate]] degree in Public Health 1995 at [[Université Cheikh Anta Diop]] in [[Dakar]], with a thesis titled ''Le SIDA en milieu chirurgical : Connaissances, attitudes et pratiques'' (in English: [[AIDS]] in the surgical arena: Knowledge, attitudes and practises). She completed a [[Master of Science]] degree at the Institut de médecine tropicale d'[[Anvers]] in 1997. She completed many specialist diplomas in [[Dakar]] and in France, as well as a [[Diplôme d'études approfondies|DEA]] in Santé publique et pays en développement (English: Public Health and Developing Countries) at l'[[Université Pierre et Marie Curie]] (Paris VI) in 2001.
At the Conseil national de la lutte contre le Sida (CNLS) (in English: National Council for the Fight Against [[AIDS]]), she directs the programs of the Fonds mondial de lutte contre cette pandémie. In 2007 she was recruited as the coordinator of the [[Joint United Nations Programme on HIV/AIDS]] program in Senegal. In 2014 she served as a consultant at GMS/OASYS Grant Management Solutions. Mali. Institute of Health and Development.
At Paris VI University she earned a Diploma of Thorough (DEA) in " Public Health and Developing Countries " (2001). At University Cheikh Anta Diop of Dakar she garnered a Certificate of Specialized Studies (CES) in Infectious and Tropical Diseases (2001). At the Institute of Tropical Medicine Antwerp in Belgium she picked up a Master of Science: Degree in Tropical Biomedical Sciences (epidemiology and disease control option) (1997). At the Paul Correa Institute of Dakar Diploma she completed a Course on Planning and Organization of control of STDs and AIDS in developing countries (1998). At the Fournier Institute Paris International she completed a Diploma Course on Sexually Transmitted Diseases (STDs). At the AIDS Institute Fournier in Paris (1998), University Cheikh Anta Diop of Dakar State she earned her Doctorate Medicine ( 1995).
== Career == In 1998 in Senegal she for UNHCR / OFADEC she was a Consultant Physician for refugee Assistance.
From August 1999 - December 2001 she worked in IMEA Physician Clinical Coordination and monitoring test cohort 1st clinical trials of antiretrovirals.
From January to December 1997 in Senegal she was a NACP research Assistant Coordinator on intervention strategies among female sex workers in Dakar. supervisions activities support and STI prevention in health districts and centers support TS (IST center ) Training of trainers on the use of guides syndromic management of STIs in the place of doctors, nurses and midwives,
From 1995-1996 she worked at the Senegal Ministry of Health as an epidemiological investigator on: diagnostic capability of STD health centers a preliminary investigation of a proposed program to fight diabetes, malaria morbidity and mortality.
From January 2002 to September 2003 Senegal DLSI / Ministry of Health Head Office Support HIV planning, support for implementation, supervision of activities Coordination of the National Steering Committee of Voluntary Counselling and Testing Coordination Committee drafting standards and Guidelines Centres Coordination Councils and Voluntary Testing the definition and implementation work of the decentralization policy initiative Senegalese antiretroviral access in areas Member of the editorial boards of documents on standards supported with antiretrovirals at health posts, health centers and hospitals member group a number of technical documents : the National Policy on injection Safety in Senegal Senegal 's proposals to the Global Fund to Fight against AIDS, tuberculosis and Malaria ; Guides syndromic management of STIs; Guides counseling and support for HIV strategic Plan 2002-2006 contrele fight AIDS ; strategic Plan to Fight against AIDS 2007-2011.
From September 2003 to March 2007 she served on the Senegal National Council Fight Against AIDS.
from April to September 2006 Senegal SE / CNLS Officer Coordinating the development of the National Strategic Plan for the Fight against AIDS (NSP 2007-2011 ) program.
In 2007 she was hired as coordinator of [[Joint United Nations Programme on HIV/AIDS|UNAIDS]] in Senegal.
On September 13, 2007, at age 44, Safiatou Thiam was Senegal's appointed Minister of Health and Prevention.
Beginning in 2009, she acted as a consultant in multiple countries for United Nations and other programs fighting AIDS, including Guinea, Burkina Faso, Mail and Cote d'Ivoire.
She coordinated the development and validation of the National Health Development Plan of Senegal (PNDS 2009-2018), Evaluation and monitoring of the implementation of the Declaration of Commitment country health; development of National health Accounts, development and validation of a policy of maintenance of medical equipment; Evaluation of Hospital Reform; development of advocacy materials in the promotion of health, the fight against disease and universal coverage of health insurance.
On February 19, 2014 she was appointed Executive Secretary of CNLS National Council for the Fight against AIDS.
