[[Rape]] |sentence=[[Capital punishment|Death]] |victims=18+ |beginyear=1996 |endyear=2002 |country=India |states=[[Karnataka]], [[Maharashtra]], [[Gujarat]] |apprehended= }} '''Umesh Reddy''' (born 1969) is a [[serial rapist]] and killer from India. He confessed to killing 18 women, and was convicted in 9 cases.{{cite news |url=http://www.daijiworld.com/news/news_disp.asp?n_id=57010 |title=Bangalore: It's Death for Cop-turned-serial-rapist Killer Umesh Reddy |date=2009-02-19 |publisher=Dajiworld }} The police believe that he raped at least 20 women in the states of [[Karnataka]], [[Maharashtra]] and [[Gujarat]]. They also suspect that several of his crimes have not been reported, because the victims feared [[social stigma]]. Reddy has been sentenced to death by the [[Supreme Court of India]], and is currently on death row. == Early life == Umesh Reddy was born BA Umesh in 1969, in Basappa Malige, a village in [[Chitradurga district]], Karnataka.{{cite news |url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/tp-karnataka/the-city-has-a-long-list-of-rogues/article6102833.ece |title=The city has a long list of rogues |newspaper=The Hindu |date=2014-06-11 }} After being selected in the [[Central Reserve Police Force]] (CRPF), he was posted in [[Jammu and Kashmir]]. While on duty as a guard at the house of a commandant, he attempted to rape the commandant's daughter. He then fled to Chitradurga district. In 1996, he managed to join the District Armed Reserve (DAR) Police, who were not aware of his background in CRPF. Reddy had been charged in a road rage incident, but the local DAR inspector chose to ignore this "petty case". Reddy completed his police training in [[Madhya Pradesh]], and then returned to Karnataka.{{cite news |url=http://www.dnaindia.com/bangalore/report-life-and-times-of-a-psychopath-killer-1232240 |title=Life and times of a psychopath-killer |date=2009-02-19 |author=Srikanth Hunasavadi |newspaper=DNA }} == Crimes == Reddy carefully selected his victims. He usually targeted [[housewife|housewives]] between 11 am and 3 pm, when there would be no men at home. He would gain entry into the victims' house on the pretext of asking for water or an address. He then threatened them with a knife, forced them to remove their clothes, tied them up, and raped them. He often choked his victims, and raped them while they were unconscious. After the rape, Reddy killed his victims, and removed their [[jewelry]] to make the crime appear like a robbery. He then escaped with the victim's undergarments. A [[transvestite]], Reddy was found wearing women's [[lingerie]] under his clothes, whenever the police arrested him. In November 1996, Reddy attempted raping a high school girl, who was walking at KEB Colony in [[Chitradurga]]. The girl hit him with a stone, and managed to escape. On 6 December 1996, Reddy allegedly raped and murdered 16-year old Roopa, when she was returning to her house in the same locality. The next month, he was arrested and dismissed from service, when his first victim identified him at a [[Republic Day (India)|Republic Day]] police parade by chance. Reddy, along with four others, was charged with Roopa's murder, and remanded to judicial custody (later, in 2004, he was acquitted in this case due to lack of sufficient evidence).{{cite news |url=http://www.thehindu.com/2004/08/08/stories/2004080804100400.htm |title=All six accused in Rupa murder case acquitted |date=2004-08-08 |newspaper=The Hindu }} A court asked him to be shifted to [[Bellary]] jail. In March 1997, while the Chitradurga police were handing him over to the Bellary prison authorities, Reddy escaped. He then killed an income tax officer's wife in [[Bangalore]], a girl in [[Ahmedabad]], two girls in [[Baroda]] and a widow in [[Kunigal]]. Reddy would steal lingerie put up for drying in the backyards of houses. On 7 July 1997, he was arrested by [[Peenya]] police for stealing women's undergarments. When the police raided his room, they recovered a [[gunny bag]] full of lingerie. At the time of his arrest in Peenya, he told the police that his name was "Ramesh". Reddy escaped within 24 hours, while being transferred to the [[Arekere Mico Layout|MICO Layout]] police station for interrogation in another case. The police initially tried to hush up his escape, but Reddy's father filed a [[habeas corpus]] petition in the High Court. Two police personnel were then suspended, and a lookout notice was issued in the name of Ramesh.{{cite news |url=http://epaper.timesofindia.com/Default/Scripting/ArticleWin.asp?From=Archive&Source=Page&Skin=pastissues2&BaseHref=TOIBG%2F2009%2F02%2F19&ViewMode=HTML&PageLabel=1&EntityId=Ar00101&AppName=2 |title=It’s gallows for Umesh Reddy: Sessions Court Sentence Upheld |newspaper=The Times of India |date=2009-02-18 }} On 28 February 1998, Reddy raped and murdered 37-year-old widow Jayashree Maradi Subbaiah in [[Peenya]]. The police believe that he repeatedly [[necrophilia|raped the dead body]]. When her 8-year-old son Suresh returned from school, he saw Reddy in his house. Reddy told the boy that an [[evil spirit]] had entered his mother's body, so he had tied her to the window [[grillwork|grill]]. He then fled saying that he was going to get a doctor.{{cite news |url=http://www.telegraphindia.com/1091108/jsp/7days/story_11713568.jsp |title=Murders most foul |author=Varun Verma |date=2009-11-08 }} Reddy then attempted to rape another woman in Peenya. When the woman raised the alarm, he tried to escape by jumping from the first floor of the house. He [[sprained ankle|sprained his ankle]], and was caught by the neighbours, who handed him over to the police. In 1999, Reddy once again escaped from the police custody near [[Hirekerur]]. Before he could commit any crime, he was arrested by inspector Nyame Gowda, in [[Chikkaballapur]]. On the night of 3–4 March 2002, Reddy escaped from police custody again, while being transferred from Bellary to Bangalore in a [[Karnataka State Road Transport Corporation|KSRTC]] bus. The District Armed Reserve (DAR) personnel of Bellary, who accompanied him, claimed that he was [[handcuffs|handcuffed]] at the time, but Reddy denied this when he was arrested two months later.{{cite news |url=http://www.thehindu.com/2002/05/18/stories/2002051802850300.htm |title=Notorious criminal Umesh Reddy nabbed |date=2002-05-18 |newspaper=The Hindu }} He stated that he bought rum and chicken for the policemen, and earned their trust. When the bus stopped at a [[dhaba]] near Hiriyur bypass, he requested the policemen to remove his handcuffs on the pretext that he needed to answer the call of nature. Once free, he ran into the fields and escaped. Over the next two months, Reddy raped three girls in [[Davangere]], [[Hubli-Dharwad]] and [[Pune]]. He also stole three mobile phones and two credit cards. He worked as a [[waiting staff|waiter]] in a Pune hotel. He stole cash and clothes from there, and then fled to Dharwad. On 17 May 2002, Reddy arrived in Bangalore from [[Tumkur]], and left his luggage in the cloakroom at the [[Yesvantpur Junction railway station|Yeshwanthpur railway station]]. Around 8 am, he visited a salon in [[Yeshwanthpur]] area, to get a haircut and a clean shave. As he entered the salon, an [[auto-rickshaw]] driver Sathyavelu recognized him from a newspaper photograph and an earlier court appearance. The driver called his elder brother Rajendran from a telephone booth, and asked him to fetch the police. Meanwhile, he kept a vigil outside the salon. When Reddy exited the salon and started walking towards the railway station, Sathyavelu tipped off the police and followed him. Inspector Nagaraja Urs intercepted Reddy near Sharief Nagar and arrested him. At first Reddy claimed to be somebody else, but admitted that he was the serial killer, after being taken to the police station. The police rewarded the driver with {{INR}} 20,000. Reddy was found wearing a bra and panties. His baggage, seized from the cloakroom, contained several women's garments: 18 pairs of panties, 10 bras, 8 [[churidar]]s, 6 [[sari]]s, 4 [[blouse]]s and 2 [[nightie]]s.{{cite news |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/bengaluru/Rapist-killer-Umesh-Reddy-caught/articleshow/10197747.cms |title=Rapist-killer Umesh Reddy caught |date=2002-05-17 |newspaper=The Times of India }} == Death sentence == Reddy was tried and convicted in 9 cases, including rape of Jayashree Subbaiah. He was acquitted in 11 cases due to lack of sufficient evidence. On 26 October 2006, Judge K Sukanya of the Bangalore city fast-track court gave him multiple [[sentence (law)|sentences]] including a death sentence, a 7-year sentence plus {{INR}} 25,000 fine and a 10-year sentence plus {{INR}} 25,000 fine. Reddy tried to win the judge's mercy by saying that he wanted to study and take care of his mother, but the judge did not relent. Since the death sentence was the heaviest sentence, the case was referred to the High Court as per procedure.{{cite news |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/bengaluru/Bangalores-Jack-the-Ripper-gets-death/articleshow/192549.cms? |title=Bangalore's Jack the Ripper gets death |date=2006-10-27 }} On 4 October 2007, a division bench of the [[Karnataka High Court]] also convicted Reddy, but the judges differed on death sentence. Justice V G Sabhahit upheld the death penalty, but Justice Ravi B Naik advocated [[rigorous imprisonment]] for life with no scope for [[amnesty]]. A third judge, Justice [[S. R. Bannurmath]], was appointed to resolve the tie. On 18 February 2009, Bannurmath upheld the death sentence, and thus, the High Court confirmed death penalty for Umesh Reddy. On 1 February 2011, the Supreme Court also upheld the death sentence. Justices [[Altamas Kabir]] and A K Pathak argued that Reddy was incapable of [[rehabilitation (penology)|rehabilitation]], and that his rape and murder of Jayashree fell under "rarest of the rare" category, a requirement for [[capital punishment in India]].{{cite news |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/bengaluru/Its-death-for-ripper-Umesh-Reddy/articleshow/7407738.cms |title=It's death for ripper Umesh Reddy |date=2011-02-02 |newspaper=The Times of India }} Reddy immediately filed a [[pardon|mercy]] petition before the [[President of India]]. On 7 May 2012, the [[Government of Karnataka]] rejected Reddy's mercy plea.{{cite news |url=http://www.deccanherald.com/content/247659/karnataka-govt-rejects-mercy-plea.html |title=Karnataka govt rejects mercy plea of serial rapist Umesh Reddy |date=2012-05-07 |newspaper=Deccan Herald }} Subsequently, the President of India also rejected his mercy petition on 12 May 2013. Reddy then filed a fresh petition, which is now pending before a Supreme Court [[Constitution Bench (India)|constitution bench]].{{cite news |url=http://indianexpress.com/article/india/india-others/mercy-denied-the-execution-list-before-nda/ |title=Mercy denied, the execution list before NDA |date=2014-09-01 |author=Muzamil Jaleel }} == In popular culture == The [[Kannada language]] movie ''Umesh'' (2013) is a fictionalized version of Umesh Reddy's life.{{cite news |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/kannada/movies/news/Umesh-Reddy-inspires-filmmakers-in-Kannada/articleshow/20424926.cms |title=Umesh Reddy inspires filmmakers in Kannada |date=2013-06-04 |newspaper=The Times of India }} ''Khatarnak'' or ''Khatarnak Umesh Reddy'' (2013), another Kannada movie, was also based on Umesh Reddy's life.{{cite news |url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/entertainment/kannada/movies/news/Kannada-film-on-Umesh-Reddy-gets-a-new-name/articleshow/23360516.cms |title=Kannada film on Umesh Reddy gets a new name |date=2013-10-01 |author=Kavya Christopher |newspaper=The Times of India }}{{cite news |url=http://www.bangaloremirror.com/entertainment/reviews/Movie-review-Khatarnak/articleshow/26223657.cms |title=Movie review: Khatarnak |author=Shyam Prasad S |newspaper=Bangalore Mirror |date=2013-11-22 }}.
